IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE – Parent Grant COVID-19 is one of the greatest threats to mankind and has caused substantial mortality, morbidity and huge economic losses. There seems to be no clear path as to when this pandemic will end, as vaccines and new therapeutics may take several months or years to come to fruition. Despite the importance of tissue-resident memory T cells in the control of viral infections and providing immunity against future infection, we do not know if SARS-CoV-2 infection generates TRM responses at the sites of infection. Here, we will employ cutting-edge single-cell RNA-seq assays to characterize properties of SARS-CoV-2 reactive TRM cells in airway/lung and tumor tissues from cancer and non-cancer patients with or without previous SARS-CoV-2 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The Yale Head and Neck SPORE is a team of clinical and laboratory researchers studying the problem of treatment resistance in head and neck cancer. Each of three projects brings a basic and clinical research leader together to study ways to overcome resistance to common therapies, such as cetuximab and cisplatin, as well as to find ways to make HPV-driven cancers more sensitive to immunotherapy. There are clinical trials to treat patients with HPV-negative and HPV-driven cancer before they go to surgery. The projects are supported by core facilities to provide administrative, pathology and statistical support, and there are funds to support new projects and new investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), a common pregnancy complication, face elevated risk for later developing type 2 diabetes. Health professionals recommend that women with GDM be screened for diabetes after delivery and participate in lifestyle programs to help prevent type 2 diabetes; however, most women do not receive these services. This study will develop an outreach strategy to help maximize the number of women with GDM who take advantage of health services for type 2 diabetes prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Particle biogenesis and assembly are necessary steps of both cell-free and cell-to-cell transmission of infectious human retroviruses, including transmission events occurring at mucosal surfaces in the oral cavity. However, viral and cellular protein determinants that are critical for cell-to-cell transmission are not fully understood. A greater understanding of viral proteins, and interactions with host cellular proteins, will help address a notable knowledge gap in the field, which will help inform the development of novel therapeutics to decrease viral transmission at mucosal surfaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: GE MEDICAL SYSTEMS INFORMATION TECHNOLOGIES, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) Our vision for the Skin Tissue Mapping Center (TMC) is to create a first-of-its-kind, comprehensive, 2D and 3D spatially-resolved multi-omic spatial atlas of normal skin comprising cell types, lipidomics, and transcriptomics. Prospective sample collection provides the unique opportunity to custom build a database with more extensive clinical information that may affect skin health. This novel spatial reference map of skin cell types spanning skin tone and location will provide critical new insights into healthy skin characteristics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  All the cells that compose our bodies arise from a single fertilized ovum and contain the same genomic information, thus during embryonic development the correct genes must be turned on and off in the right cells at the right times to grow and maintain an individual capable of independent life. The work proposed here will integrate cutting edge techniques to directly visualize and quantify how this regulation of gene expression is orchestrated during embryonic development. The critical new information that will be gained from the proposed experiments have the potential to lead to novel therapeutic approaches to prevent or repair defects that arise from aberrant gene expression during development, in aging, and in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Endocrine interactions have been demonstrated as causal and contributory to most common, most notably obesity, type 2 diabetes and resulting cardiovascular complications. The goal of this proposal is to closely bridge computational and experimental methods to systematically dissect mechanisms by which tissues communicate and how these interactions are perturbed in disease settings. Collectively, we will begin with newly developed and unbiased computational approaches which survey population data, validate using high-throughput in vitro assays and evaluate therapeutic potential of new endocrine interactions using mouse models of metabolic disease.

PHR: CORE D: NARRATIVE The overall goal of the Program Project is to develop an adaptive learning platform for breast cancer risk prediction and tailored prevention strategies, integrating novel biomarkers of risk. The Patient Centered Outcomes and Cost-Effectiveness Core will be responsible for improving translation of personalized data into breast cancer screening and risk reduction behaviors, creating psycho-educational and motivational tools for patients and providers, improve communication, and integrate patient-centered outcome measures with an enhanced focus on adherence and non-adherence within the Projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African trypanosomes are parasites that infect humans and cause the fatal blood-borne disease known as sleeping sickness. Parasite survival and its ability to infect humans depends on two key enzymes that modify the structural organization of DNA, thereby impacting gene regulation of the parasite. Our research will advance our mechanistic understanding of how these critical enzymes control essential biological processes in trypanosomes, potentially leading to the development of inhibitor drugs that can be used to treat and/or cure sleeping sickness and related diseases caused by tropical parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Stanford U54 SARS-CoV-2 Serological Sciences Center of Excellence is a member of the SeroNet consortium organized to address the urgent need for better understanding of human immune responses to the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus and vaccines targeting it. In the proposed Supplement funding for this award, we will carry out further investigations into SARS-CoV-2-specific responses in pregnancy; deep characterization of the evolution of B cell memory through the pandemic; structural studies of protective antibodies bound to their antigens; extensive analysis of class I epitope presentation of SARS-CoV-2 across human HLA alleles; and in- depth T cell and B cell analyses in patients with long Covid. The combined impact of these studies will be to extend understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms affecting immune responses to the continuing evolving SARS-CoV-2 viral populations in individuals with different prior exposure histories, and in some populations such as pregnant individuals or long Covid patients who have altered immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PHANTOM AND AUTOMATED ANALYSIS FOR ADVANCED COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY SYSTEMS Narrative This application is a supplement application to U01 EB034205-01, “Multiple x-ray source array (MXA) computed tomography”. In this proposal, the existing modular CT image quality phantom (called “Corgi”, produced commercially by the Phantom Laboratory) will be upgraded to include an additional module which includes the ability for automated analysis for both volume and texture accuracy, as well as software upgrades to include task-based model observer performance. The supplemental application will also address how these updates to the Corgi phantom will impact our assessment of the prototype CT scanner produced in the parent award and will also develop the users group to assess the utility of the new phantom module, the accompanying software analysis tools available online, and the NIST/NIBIB Phantom lending library infrastructure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Serologic testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies is a critical tool for understanding the epidemiology and designing control strategies for the COVID-19 pandemic. Within a large, integrated health system with rich demographic, behavioral and clinical data, we will develop and implement a large- scale, population-based, flexible platform to assess SARS-CoV-2 sero-prevalence, sero-incidence, risk of sero-conversion and longevity of antibody response. This study will be critical in enhancing our understanding of how to use commercially available, large-scale SARS-CoV-2 antibody testing for population-level and individual-level disease control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: This study tests the effectiveness of an innovative youth leadership and civic engagement program with a mindfulness component co-constructed with youth of color and designed to improve their wellbeing. In partnership with METCO in Boston, MA and Chicago Public Schools in Chicago, IL, we propose a randomized control trial to test the LEAP-M program. The novel LEAP-M study may be the only study that evaluates a youth activism and leadership program with a mindfulness-based intervention focusing on structural and neighborhood factors that youth of color aspire to change as a way to improve their wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is an inflammatory skin disease with many unmet medical needs and a poorly resolved genetic architecture. Inborn errors of immunity (IEI) are single-gene disorders comprising a class of nearly 500 extensively studied genes that contribute to the genetic architecture of prevalent multifactorial disorders and can have important clinical implications for the patients that have an IEI by presenting opportunities for targeted interventions and individualized screening. Here we will identify HS research participants with an IEI, validate biological and clinical consequences of identified mutations, and establish gene-level and pathway- level evidence with exome burden testing and genome-wide association studies.

PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) is the major form of human diabetes, accounting for approximately 90–95% of diagnosed diabetes cases in the United States. Our research is designed to provide insight into how the brain contributes to blood glucose regulation in T2D. Specifically, we aim to identify the neural factors responsible for the development of T2D and address a novel liver glucose metabolism-based mechanism of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Johns Hopkins Excellence in Pathogenesis and Immunity Center for SARS-CoV-2 (JH-EPICS) Overall Narrative The goal of the Johns Hopkins Excellence in Pathogenesis and Immunity Center for SARS-CoV-2 (JH-EPICS) is to define the immune responses that can either protect or harm during infection. The JH-EPICS team will evaluate the immune responses required to detect the presence of SARS-CoV-2, initiate inflammatory responses, eliminate infected cells, and engage the antibody responses against the virus in COVID-19 patients. Using statistical analyses and modeling, JH-EPICS will identify the variables, such as demographic (e.g., age, sex, gender, race, and ethnicity) and clinical (e.g., severity of COVID-19 and comorbidities) factors, that predict COVID-19 immune responses and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Dengue vaccine development and evaluation is challenged by a lack of immunological correlates of protection and risk. A continued lack of understanding of durable protective immunity and, perhaps a more acute need, immune profiles that present increased risk threatens to present another failure of evaluation of current dengue vaccine candidates. Here, we propose to capture the diversity of non- neutralizing antibody and cellular responses from infection and vaccination alongside neutralizing responses to develop a better understanding of immunity and risk of dengue infection and illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mitochondria, often described as power-houses of the cell, accumulate at sites within nerve cells where the power is needed. We are investigating the mechanisms that distribute mitochondria to where they are most needed to maintain the essential function of nerve cells. A better understanding of these mechanisms is essential, as a number of neurodegenerative diseases are associated with a failure of mitochondria to supply power as needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Constructing reliable individualized treatment strategies requires studies with fairly large sample sizes with longi- tudinal assessment of subjects over a relatively long period of time. To this end, we will create a harmonized and curated dataset by integrating data from seven long-term observational and randomized studies in Parkinson's disease. Using this harmonized data, we will develop and apply robust, rigorous and computationally efﬁcient methods for estimating an optimal individualized treatment strategy for Parkinson's disease with respect to var- ious outcomes (e.g., Uniﬁed Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale, quality of life, and Schwab and England ADL score). We will also leverage statistical machine learning approaches to improve the quality of the constructed optimal individualized treatment strategy while providing valid statistical inference.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) The inability of tracking the locations of the alpha emitter 225Ac inside live subjects is hindering the adoption of targeted alpha therapy, an extremely promising cancer radiotherapy technique that uses the unique properties of alpha radiation to boost safety and efficacy. To overcome this major limitation, we propose a novel imaging system capable of imaging 225Ac pharmaceuticals during treatment of small animals by using a novel combination of two imaging techniques: Compton and proximity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will involve a pilot study to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and outcomes of regular lifestyle behavior (RLB i.e. regular sleep, exercise, mealtime) protocol in managing chronic migraine. Additionally, the proposal will investigate biomolecules that are uniquely involved in chronic migraine patients who respond to RLB. Successful completion of this proposal will inform the design of a future full- scale clinical trial testing the efficacy of RLB in chronic migraine, as well as provide the candidate with intensive, supervised training to help him become an independent research scientist focusing on headache medicine, more specifically on managing migraine using health-promoting lifestyle behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Immunocompromised patients are at a higher risk for COVID-19 infection and poor outcome, are more likely to suffer from prolonged viral replication that fosters the development and propagation of new variants and have a poorer response to current vaccines. Of particular interest are patients treated with therapies that compromise the function of antibody-producing B cells and plasma cells (patients with autoimmune diseases and lymphoid malignancies such as lymphoma and myeloma) and lung cancer patients treated with immunotherapy. In this supplemental application, we will further investigate the precise immunological basis for these defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis is the most commonly used drug among people who drink alcohol, and conflicting evidence suggests that cannabinoids (the chemical constituents of the cannabis plant, including delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol [THC]) may confer both harms and benefits on the symptoms of alcohol use disorder (AUD). Animal studies suggest the effects of cannabis among heavy drinkers may be partially due to the impact of THC on the microbiota-gut-brain axis (MGBA; which refers to the bidirectional communication between the digestive, immune, and central nervous systems), however no human studies have explicitly explored this question. This observational study will inform our understanding of the risks and potential harm-reduction benefits of cannabis among heavy drinkers by investigating the effects of THC in legal-market cannabis on acute and daily alcohol consumption, AUD symptoms, and MGBA function among heavy drinking, regular cannabis users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Iron deficiency suppresses red cell production by the bone marrow, leading to several types of human anemia, including anemia associated with kidney disease. Better understanding of the mechanism for this marrow suppression is needed to improve monitoring and treatment of these conditions. We have recently discovered new, unanticipated components of this mechanism that involve factors previously associated with neural function, -synuclein and dopamine. Delineating the role of these factors in anemia development will enable development of novel treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Animal studies have demonstrated that the regulation of food intake requires articulation among endogenous cannabinoids (ECs), fatty acid-binding proteins (FABPs), and a peroxisome proliferator- activated nuclear receptor (PPARa), but the macromolecular basis for appetite, satiety, and obesity is poorly understood. This project will probe the solution-state macromolecular structure and function of EC- FABP, EC-PPAR, and FABP-EC-PPAR complexes in vitro at near-physiological concentrations, determining affinities, metabolic fates, molecular binding interfaces, and conformational changes to test proposed mechanisms of EC metabolic signaling. Working as a team with research trainees, our work will help to understand health risks and design future therapies for heart disease, autoimmune disorders, and type-2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to develop Rabies Barcode Interaction Detection followed by sequencing (RaBID-seq), a high- throughput, scalable technology to map the brain-wide monosynaptic inputs to thousand or even millions of neurons in a single animal. We will improve the experimental scalability of RaBID-seq, benchmark RaBID-seq connectivity against gold-standard techniques for assessment of synaptic connectivity, and develop new compu- tational tools to infer monosynaptic wiring from barcoded viral datasets. This new technology will transform our ability to apply brain-wide circuit mapping at scale with synaptic resolution and to identify the transcriptomic cell type of each mapped pre- and post-synaptic neuron.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetic foot ulceration is a devastating complication of diabetes that compromises the quality of life, increases risks for lower extremity amputations and further increases risk of death. The main aim is to develop a proteomics biomarker signature prognostic for diabetic wound healing and initiate the determination of its clinical utility. These advances will offer long-term potential for accelerating prognostication tools and biomarker-guided drug development strategies in this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) are a devastating complication of diabetes and represent a major risk factor for amputation of the affected foot. This proposal will non-invasively measure small RNAs in the urine of patients with DFUs and study their ability to predict early which ulcers are unlikely to heal with standard DFU treatments. Results of this project will allow clinicians to promptly identify hard-to-heal DFUs that warrant early intensive therapies, increasing the likelihood of ulcer closure and minimizing pain and risks of serious complications from a chronically open wound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes affects over 37 million people in the US, with 90% having type 2 diabetes (T2D). Our overarching objective is to unravel the significance of ER stress in β-cell survival and function under metabolic stress caused by obesity, aging, and lifestyle changes. This research is crucial in the fight against diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a lethal cancer with a 5-year survival rate ~10% and is predicted to become the second deadliest cancer within the next 10 years. Epigenetic changes regulating gene expression have become a focus of intense research to help in the development of new treatment for this dismal condition. This proposal will investigate the role of nuclear myosins in chromatin organization leading epigenetic silencing of gene expression during PDAC transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Directing the immune system to kill cancer cells is a highly potent way of treating cancer. Abnormal addition of carbohydrates to proteins is a near universal feature of cancer, however current immunotherapies cannot readily target these. Here we propose to further develop a novel technology that directs immune cells to kill cancer cells based on expression of altered carbohydrates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver cancer, also known as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), is the fastest growing cause of cancer-related deaths among Americans with liver disease. Fatty liver disease related to metabolic dysfunction (e.g., diabetes, obesity), also called MAFLD, has become the most common liver disease in the world. Our research is significant because it investigates several risk factors and novel biomarkers that can be reliably used to identify subgroups of MAFLD patients with an increased HCC risk, so they can be targeted for prevention and early detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths, accounting for 25% of all cancer mortalities - more than colon, breast, and prostate cancer combined. We propose to develop a nanotherapeutic named PETTRA that simultaneously targets PLK1 and EGFR in approximately 50% of all lung cancer patients regardless of mutational status. PETTRA will be a first-in-class molecularly-targeted therapy that is also a radiation sensitizer for lung cancer, which will benefit about 60% of patients undergoing radiation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic testing for characterizing and identifying hereditary risk related to carrier screening, newborn screening, and cancer predisposition testing has transformed prevention and care efforts for many, yet underserved groups like Latinx groups are benefiting at the same rate as white populations. A critical understudied area of genetic testing utilization for Latinx groups is perceived facilitators and barriers, and without a robust understanding of these factors, strategic communication campaigns likely will not have desired effects of improved genetic testing utilization. Thus, the current study will characterize attitudes, facilitators, and barriers of Latinx individuals' experiences with genetic testing using semistructured elicitation interviews, then testing associations between these factors with a designed survey from interviews administered with a Qualtrics Panel of 500 Latinx individuals to identify the best factors for intervention using culturally appropriate translational strategic communication research efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies of the visual experience of infants are relevant to public health because impaired vision and visual learning have long term consequences across many domains of a healthy and successful life. Disrupted visual experience in infancy is evident in the continued risk in perceptual, cognitive and school achievements and is implicated in the nexus of disrupted visual learning and motor development of children with more general developmental disorders. Determining the expected and normative early visual input in infancy and its links to infant eye- movements and behaviors is expected to give rise to new diagnostics and behavioral interventions for at-risk infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: APPLICATION NARRATIVE Optic neuropathy is a class of devastating vision threatening diseases that affect the optic nerve, and there are no methods to selectively deliver therapeutics to the optic nerve head. A delivery technique to the optic nerve head will be developed, and the safety, distribution, and efficacy will be compared against intravitreal and intraorbital optic nerve injections. Delivery techniques to the optic nerve head could improve treatment options for optic neuropathies, and facilitate further studies on disease pathogenesis and treatment options for millions of patients with optic neuropathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of death and disease among Black American women and is associated with pregnancy complications and experiences of early and chronic stress. We will measure health and behavioral indicators of CVD risk in a sample of Black women who have participated in a 20-year longitudinal study to examine the effects of lifetime stress exposure and stress reactivity on profiles of CVD risk across the first two years postpartum. New data from this study will improve understanding of CVD risk specific to Black women, and will inform the targets and timing of interventions to reduce persistent racial disparities in maternal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop and validate privacy-preserving multimodal machine/deep learning (ML/DL) models for the early detection of cachexia across multiple cancer types and risk stratification of PDAC from IPMNs using clinical, imaging, genetic mutational, and social determinants of health (SDOH) data. To access large-scale representative data while respecting the privacy and the security of sensitive patient data, this proposal leverages Federated Learning (FL). Moffitt Cancer Center will act as a server and as a site for other projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elder neglect by a caregiver can have serious health consequences for older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias but it is seldom identified and addressed. We propose to develop a screening tool for primary care providers to improve identification of elder neglect and a point-of-care intervention to support caregivers who may be neglecting an older adult. Findings from this research will improve the ability of health care providers to identify, intervene, and prevent neglect and improve the health of this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The field of Redox Biology is rapidly advancing with the introduction of improved tools and insight to understand how disrupted redox-regulated signaling pathways contribute to pathogenesis of pulmonary vascular diseases. This project will establish how the content or distribution of a critical vascular antioxidant enzyme, extracellular superoxide dismutase, contributes to pathologic redox regulated signaling in pulmonary hypertension and provide the foundation for novel targeted therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Despite advances in clinical care and education, gaps remain in the evidence base to inform clinical palliative care, especially for older adults. One of the most important ways to advance care for older adults with advanced illness is through the development of junior investigators who will contribute to generation of evidence and build the academic critical mass necessary for the future of the field. Although clinical fellowship programs in palliative care have been growing in number and quality, there remains a paucity of research training opportunities in palliative care. The goal of this T32 is to prepare postdoctoral physician and PhD scientists for careers as aging-related palliative care researchers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Research Training in Palliative Care

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN) includes 24 pediatric intensive care units and an established Data Coordinating Center with independent medical and biostatistical expertise. Build- ing on its strong track record of successful clinical trials and innovative work in immune phenotyping in pediatric sepsis, the CPCCRN will carry out a large-scale multicenter randomized controlled trial using personalized test- ing and targeted management of immune function in infants and children with sepsis-induced multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), one of the most frequent causes of mortality and morbidity in critical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is common, deadly, and costly, and adults with insomnia represent a large group of people at elevated risk of developing CVD in the future. This mechanistic study will determine if our updated insomnia treatment called SHADES improves biological factors thought to explain how insomnia promotes CVD and if these improvements are due to positive changes in sleep factors. This study could generate the critical evidence needed to justify a large clinical trial to determine if SHADES can help prevent CVD events, such as heart attacks and strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Gain of function mutations in motor protein KIF5A are an emerging cause of pathogenesis in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) and Frontotemporal Degeneration (FTD). This proposal investigates how ALS/FTD causative mutations in KIF5A affect its function in axonal transport and cytoskeletal regulation. Our findings will provide insights into the critical roles KIF5A in neuronal health and lay the foundation for rational design of therapeutics to treat KIF5A ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this multi-site study, we will link geospatial environmental measures with electronic health records from health systems across the United States to elucidate the scope and magnitude of pediatric health risks resulting from extreme weather events, such as heatwaves and intense rainstorms. Results will provide evidence of acute health impacts from recent weather extremes, as well as novel data on chronic health outcomes associated with exposure to multiple extreme weather events over time. Quantification of disproportionate impacts borne by marginalized community-member children will provide information that is critically needed to support policies intended to prevent further harm from climate extremes and to promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because Latino children are disproportionately affected by short sleep duration, poorly timed sleep, and obesity by the age of 3 years, it is critical to understand factors that may contribute to both sleep and obesity in this population. This study will advance our understanding of how environmental (e.g., household, neighborhood, societal), sociocultural (e.g., acculturation, beliefs), and parental (e.g., sleep-related parenting practices) factors contribute to toddler sleep and toddler weight status over a 2-year period in Mexican American families, one of the largest growing ethnic minority populations in the U.S. By identifying contextual factors and modifiable behaviors that must be considered for intervention design, this study will contribute to the development of family-focused, culturally-tailored, and contextually-informed early prevention programs focused on sleep and weight status in this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Robinson, James E Project Narrative SARS-CoV-2, the virus which causes COVID-19, is one of the most devastating human pathogens of our time. The Tulane University COVID Antibody and Immunity Network (TUCAIN) will mechanistically define the immune response to this virus to determine how it protects individuals from infection and how long that protection lasts. By creating large integrated data sets of immunological and clinical data as well as characterized blood samples, we will be able to construct sophisticated methods to diagnose, and improve treatment of infected individuals. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Current therapies for autoimmune disease chronically suppress the immune system, which risks severe infection. DSG3-CAART is the first precision T cell immunotherapy for autoimmune disease to enter clinical trials, which presents a unique opportunity to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of this novel targeted therapeutic approach in humans. The proposed studies will elucidate the cellular and molecular determinants of DSG3-CAART activity and host immune response, using clinical samples collected from subjects enrolled in the DSG3-CAART phase 1 study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging data demonstrate that most people with epilepsy are more likely to have seizures at certain times of the day. However, the mechanisms that underlie these daily rhythms in seizures remain unclear. This proposal seeks to leverage the power of the fly model system to identify underlying cellular and circuit mechanisms, with the end goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets and improving our ability to predict seizure occurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Engaging in regular physical activity during midlife is a key lifestyle behavior associated with reduced risk for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD). Yet nearly half of midlife adults (48%) do not meet national physical activity guidelines. The purpose of this mechanistic trial is to identify effective goal setting techniques to enhance psychosocial processes of self-regulation for the successful promotion of PA and adherence to national PA guidelines among midlife adults, with the long-term goal of reducing AD/ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pulmonary sarcoidosis has unknown cause and severe manifestations significantly impair quality of life and can result in lung transplant and death. Exposure to bacterial and fungal products is thought to play a role, yet there is great need to understand why some patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis develop severe lung disease. We will measure how residential exposure to bacteria and fungi contribute to severe sarcoidosis lung disease which will eventually lead to optimal treatment strategies, such as household environmental remediation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elder mistreatment affects approximately one in ten older adults, worsening their health, wellbeing, and mortality, with serious costs to families, health care systems, and society making it one of the most pressing public health problems for older adults in the U.S. For people living with dementia, rates approach 50%, with risk factors that arise from a complicated and interwoven set of characteristics distributed among people and circumstances. Through the proposed study, we will develop and implement a risk assessment screen and an intervention in primary care settings focused on family care partners/caregivers that will lead to the primary prevention of elder mistreatment in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sexual conflict occurs when males and females have divergent strategies to reach their respective fitness optima, and is thought to drive morphological innovations, behaviors, and even contribute to speciation. However, the genes involved remain unknown. My proposed research will define the generality of sexual conflict-driven new gene evolution and how these new genes facilitate sex-specific functions to mediate or resolve sexual conflict.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Repeated cycles of binge alcohol intoxication and withdrawal are associated with impaired social behaviors, compounding interpersonal problems associated with alcohol abuse and hastening the progression to alcohol use disorder (AUD). Unfortunately, few treatment options are currently available that specifically address the social symptoms of alcohol abuse. This study will employ a rodent model of binge alcohol consumption to elucidate serotonergic mechanisms of alcohol’s deleterious effect on social behavior, with an eye toward developing new treatments for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Cyclic GMP synthesis in photoreceptors enables vision. Abnormalities in the cGMP synthesis impair rod and cone vision and cause congenital retinal diseases. In this application, we seek better understanding of the molecular mechanisms regulating cGMP synthesis in biological function and disease of photoreceptors. This knowledge can help understand the origins of congenital blindness and design strategies for their treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic liver disease is a major contributor to morbidity and mortality worldwide, in part because there are no therapies to delay progression or promote resolution of hepatic fibrosis, the end stage pathology of chronic liver disease. Activation of the blood clotting cascade is associated with chronic liver disease progression, but the specific mechanisms linking clotting factors to deposition of scar tissue (i.e., collagen) in the injured liver are poorly understood. The primary goal of this research proposal is to uncover precisely how blood clotting factors interact with collagen-producing cells in the injured liver so that new therapies can be designed to delay the progression of liver fibrosis in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Photodynamic therapy (PDT), in combination with surgery, offers a potential locally curative treatment and has been demonstrated in clinical trials, including in malignant mesothelioma, to substantially prolong patient survival. In this translational project we will optimize singlet oxygen dosimetry instruments and novel phantoms for direct quantitative measurements of the major cytotoxic agent (excited-state singlet oxygen) generated in PDT, which could significantly improve the accuracy and hence efficacy of this modality, both for this particular clinical application and more generally in other tumor sites. Being fiberoptic based, the technology will be suitable for implementation in any tumor site that is accessible to PDT (interstitial, endoscopic, intraoperative).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use remains the leading cause of preventable death, and racialized and socioeconomic inequities in tobacco use and related diseases persist. Innovative public health policies to reduce neighborhood TRA equitably are needed, especially in preempted states. This study will be the first to evaluate whether use-based zoning tobacco control policies can be intentionally designed to decrease neighborhood tobacco retailer availability equitably: findings from this study may open the door for a new suite of policy tools that can promote tobacco control and health equity nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The diffuse optics technique holds promise as a bedside cerebral blood flow monitoring tool for screen, diagnosis and therapeutic management of many brain-related diseases. In this supplement, we will characterize and optimize the optical phantoms mimicking multilayered microvascular cerebral blood flow. We envision the phantoms will serve as a standard reference for daily calibration, performance evaluation and quality control, contributing to clinical translation of light-based microvascular flowmeter through wide dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous monitoring of blood pressure can help the early diagnosis of developing cardiovascular disease, reveal short term blood pressure variations, and help the physician monitor the response to medication for hypertensive patients. Current industrial and academic technology development for continuous cuffless blood pressure has a primary focus on optical technologies which does not operate satisfactorily on darker skin tones and those with higher BMI. Our proposed efforts will directly address this critical limitation through development of a technology that will operate satisfactorily in communities of color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Falls are a major public health concern, especially for people living with dementia; yet precise and practical fall detection systems are lacking. This project will conduct both lab and field studies (n=168 participants) to assess the accuracy of Theora® 360, an innovative automated fall detection system that uses Ultra Wideband technology combined with motion sensors to detect falls and assess mobility changes, fall risk, and fall context among community-dwelling people living with dementia (PLWD). Usability studies will also be built in to help ensure that system components are user-friendly. Successful completion can provide a valuable resource for PLWD to pursue aging in place and for caregivers to advance care while reducing caregiving burdens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Adiponectin is a protein that circulates in high levels in the blood and which has known protective effects on the cardiovascular system. Aging impairs vascular function, but late-life exercise can reverse much of the vascular dysfunction related to advancing age. The overall goal of this application is to determine whether adiponectin plays a role in 1) the vascular dysfunction that occurs with advancing age, and 2) the ability of exercise training to promote vascular resiliency and reverse age-related vascular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Establishing the CANOE Partnership as a resource within the infrastructure of the Consortium solidifies our previous efforts into an entity within an ecosystem of success regarding the fight against cancer mortality among our relatives. We anticipate that while this is a significant step toward Indigenous Cancer Health Equity, it remains a beginning to a long journey ahead and look forward to continuing these efforts in partnership with our Tribal and community collaborators, and with NIMHD as a strong partner in a long term relationship with a unified purpose: Achieving equitable outcomes for not only the cancers upon which the current projects focus; those with the highest cost in lives, but eventually across all cancer outcomes and across the entirety of Indian Country.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) mortality is linked to modifiable health behaviors such as physical activity, alcohol intake, and diet; however, <10% of CRC survivors adhere to health behavior recommendations (HBR) after diagnosis. In non-cancer populations, personalized self-management training programs have been associated with increased adherence to HBR when compared to standardized interventions, but a personalized approach to lifestyle self-management has not yet been tested in a cancer population. This prospective, two-parallel-arm, randomized controlled trial will test whether a personalized self-management training intervention improves adherence to HBR among CRC patients when compared to a standardized health behavior education control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Post-surgical pain is a major contributor to chronic pain, opioid dependence, and opioid substance abuse. While anesthesiologists have many tools for treating surgical and post-operative pain, they have no tools to monitor how well their treatments might be working, making it difficult if not impossible to accurately and reliably treat nociception during surgery and minimize post-operative pain. In this project we will develop a promising novel technology to actively assess pain and analgesia during general and regional anesthesia.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with bipolar disorder (BP) and comorbid substance use disorders (SUDs) have poor treatment adherence and poor clinical outcomes, high rates of suicide, and increased psychiatric hospitalization. They are at particularly high risk for treatment nonadherence when transitioning from psychiatric hospitalization to outpatient care, with little to no treatment options available to improve care of this high-risk population at the critical period following hospital discharge. The current project will test the effectiveness of Integrated Treatment Adherence Program (ITAP), which is the first adjunctive psychosocial program specifically designed to improve treatment adherence and reduce suicidality, bipolar symptoms, and substance use among high-risk patients with BP-SUD. If shown effective, ITAP could be easily and efficiently adopted as standard care for hospitalized Veterans with co-occurring BP and SUD within VHA. Findings from this study will inform clinical and policy efforts on the implementation of BP treatment for Veterans with co-occurring SUD post-discharge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain is a debilitating side effect of many chemotherapeutics. The neuropathies are the principle reason why many patients stop potential curative therapy, impacting their survival. This project will validate novel mechanism-based molecular targets for the prevention and treatment of chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain which might hasten the development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Invasive melanoma is a potentially deadly medical condition, with an incidence of 100,000 new cases in 2021 alone. Melanoma research has mainly focused on melanocyte dysregulation to understand the disease; yet, the epidermis is an important microenvironment for healthy melanocytes, which adhere to and communicate with keratinocytes to maintain homeostasis. In this project, we will test hypothesis that melanocytes and epidermal cells form specialized adhesions important for melanocyte migration and retention within the epidermis, thereby contributing to the suppression of melanoma metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching research theme for the Mount Sinai U54 is to understand factors that may compromise the immune response of lung cancer patients following SARS-CoV-2 infection or vaccination in comparison to a matched “healthy” control group. Comprehensive serologic and cellular analyses of serially collected blood samples from consented patients coupled to a highly annotated database of patient clinical and demographic factors will be used to identify vulnerabilities inherent to this patient population, augmented by in vitro modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to utilize the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) to assess alcohol use disparities between sexual minority youth (SMY) and heterosexual youth at the intersections of multiple marginalized identities including sex and race/ethnicity, and to determine how these associations impact HIV vulnerability. The team’s pooled dataset, which contains 950,295 youth from local versions of the YRBS, will be extended to include YRBS data collected between 2021 and 2025, providing the opportunity to conduct innovative, intersectional research on the associations between alcohol use, HIV vulnerabilities, and mental health on a national scale and adapt novel methodologies for this purpose. This project builds upon a highly successful prior R01 which facilitated critical health disparities research, interdisciplinary collaboration, and high-impact publication, by strengthening the available sample and leveraging additional modes of complex quantitative inquiry to support innovation in analysis and application of results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Latino adults in the United States (U.S.) are 1.5 times more likely to develop Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) compared to non-Hispanic White adults and although treatment of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) reduces OSA symptoms, improves cognition and quality of life, no existing studies have focused on improving treatment adherence to positive airway pressure (PAP) in this population. This project proposes to develop and test Nuestro Sueño, the first, culturally-adapted PAP adherence and sleep health intervention for Latino couples. The results of this study could significantly reduce the burden of OSA for patients and their partners, and may identify a novel target of preventing ADRD among Latinos, who remain under-represented in both ADRD and sleep disorders research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In direct response to RFA-AG-22-024, we propose stage IA research (R61 phase) to adapt the Detection of Elder abuse Through Emergency Care Technicians (DETECT) screening tool for home-based primary care — with special emphasis on older adults who were recently diagnosed with AD/ADRD — The DETECT Revision for Primary Care (DETECT-RPC). We also propose a stage III multisite randomized (at the provider level) controlled efficacy trial (R33 phase) of DETECT-RPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For decades, pregnant individuals who identify as Black have been considered at greatest risk for hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP), cardiovascular complications, and maternal mortality; as such, the social construct of race carries arguably the heaviest weight for Black pregnant individuals, whose current state has been described as a public health crisis in the United States. The proposed research provides many experimental opportunities to greatly impact multiple fields of research including: allostatic load, HDP, post- pregnancy cardiovascular health, and racial disparities among each. The findings will inform the development of evidence-based interventions that will focus on narrowing racial health disparities and improving pregnancy outcomes and cardiovascular health in females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Experiences of stress and trauma across the life course may result in poor cardiometabolic outcomes during pregnancy, postpartum, and later life. This project aims to use data on stress and trauma across the life course to examine the impact of cumulative stress on cardiometabolic function during pregnancy and following childbearing and cardiometabolic risk behaviors postpartum. The results of this project will inform theory, potential intervention development, and the understanding of the impact of stress and trauma on health.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This mixed methods study will use a large multi-site linked nurse and patient sample and econometric techniques for causal inference, to examine how nurse specialty certifications may impact individual nurse performance and patient outcomes and costs. The study will provide robust, causal, and reliable evidence to inform organizational investments in nurse human capital to optimize nurse performance, achieve targeted patient outcomes, and reduce costs of care, thus directly responding to AHRQ’s priority to increase the affordability and efficiency of care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The impact of specialty nursing certification on patient outcomes and costs in acute care: An individual value-added performance analysis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT: PROJECT NARRATIVE ICON will expand authentic tribal-cancer center capacity to improve cancer outcomes for American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) persons through a coordinated program of research projects addressing three major cancer research priorities identified by our AI/AN stakeholders - prevention, screening and cancer care coordination. Career enhancement activities for ICON investigators will be integrated into the research projects and curricula will focus on the conduct of research in the context of tribal sovereignty. All of this will be accomplished through ICON’s unmatched approaches to community engagement with Tribal Nations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental factors that can be modified at community-scale, including air pollution and features of the built and natural environment, may affect the risk of developing diabetes. Better understanding of the relationship between environmental factors and diabetes will help in the development of cost-effective policies to protect public health and reduce health inequality—critical parts of the NIH mission. This study will investigate these relationships in Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos and help to understand the inter- relationship between development of diabetes and traffic-related air pollution, the neighborhood built environment, and the intensity and location of physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant advances in human neurosciences emerging from direct intracranial recordings of brain activity in human volunteers, it can be difficult to fully interpret these signals because of an incomplete understanding of the factors that affect their quality and patterns. This is further complicated by the relative rarity of these signals which make it challenging to conduct the large scale studies that are needed to study the factors that may contribute to signal variability, such as underlying brain anatomy. In this project, we use the power of numbers derived from the Data Archive for the BRAIN Initiative which hosts data from over 535 subjects from 24 institutions to create a large integrated multimodal dataset to enable large scale analyses of these brain signals and their significance, especially as it pertains to the influence of brain anatomy on these neural signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Substance abuse disorders are a chronic human condition where initial consumption leads to long-lasting behavioral changes, driven in part by initial, and then progressive resistance to the intoxicating effects of alcohol as tolerance develops. The results of the proposed studies will provide valuable mechanistic insight into the way initial ethanol exposure causes these long-lasting behavioral changes. This will highlight novel targets for therapeutic intervention with alcohol addiction, which are largely lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project 1 NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality that affects nearly 300,000 women worldwide each year, and its poor outcomes are related to delayed diagnosis and development of resistance to conventional therapy with carboplatin, paclitaxel and PARP inhibitors. Inhibition of salt induced kinase 2 (SIK2) has enhanced sensitivity to all three agents. Our proposal will explore the ability of GRN-300, a SIK-2 inhibitor, to enhance response to the PARP inhibitor olaparib and to immune checkpoint blockade, enhancing their antitumor activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Urban children with asthma are at high risk for short sleep, due to an environment that jeopardizes both sleep and asthma management. Further, urban children with asthma suffer from altered immune balance, a key biological process contributing to individual differences in asthma morbidity and sleep health. In the proposed research, we will examine the effects of shortened and recovery sleep on immune balance and associated changes in lung function in urban children with allergic asthma through an experimental design.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses are highly transmissible in chickens, causing 100% mortality within days and leading to significant economic losses and potentially severe public health risks if transmitted to humans. This project aims to develop gene modified chickens with reduced susceptibility or resistance to HPAI and other avian viruses by genetically targeting pro-viral host factors, antiviral proteins, or viral genes. Innovatively creating a single gene modified chicken line resistant to multiple viral pathogens could dramatically reduce disease burden and economic losses in the poultry industry.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Building Resistance Against Viral Entities (BRAVE) Innovation Center

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in spatial learning and memory occur in many psychiatric and neurological disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, posttraumatic stress disorder, depression, Alzheimer’s disease, stroke, and traumatic brain injury), and the neural mechanism of these deficits may involve a distinct loss in specific spatial reference frames or a loss in coordination across reference frames, such as determining the appropriate action for an allocentric location and orientation (e.g., turn right when oriented north at a specific location). Further investigation of these basic neurobiological mechanisms underlying spatial navigation is critically important for establishing a complete understanding of the neural underpinnings of spatial deficits in psychiatric disorders, neurological disorders, brain disease, and stroke. Such investigation will facilitate the development of more precise diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions to help manage or reverse these diseased and disordered brain states and on a broader level, it will further our understanding of the neural basis of episodic memory, recognizing objects from a variety of viewpoints, and potentially even inform understanding of basic organizing principles of the brain.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is an infectious disease that continues to cause extensive morbidity and mortality throughout tropical and sub-tropical regions of the developing world, especially among young children in sub-Saharan Africa. This project focuses on the ability of malaria parasites to avoid the human immune response and to cause severe disease. A better understanding of these processes will lead to new forms of treatment that will help to relieve the enormous public health burden that malaria inflicts on the developing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eating habits that are uncontrollable and persist without respect to negative consequences are compulsive and can be observed in both obesity and eating disorders. Motivated behavior is controlled by brain circuits that are sensitive to how hungry we are, but how hunger changes the responsivity of these circuits to negative consequences associated with eating is unknown. This project will test the hypothesis that hunger modulates the communication of negative consequences to motivational brain regions, and will improve our understanding of how these mechanisms can contribute to compulsive eating.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding diseases, including diabetes, pancreatitis, and cancers, requires a comprehensive knowledge of how cells and tissues normally respond to stress to maintain stability. Important aspects of this are controlled by the organization and structure of the DNA within cells. We will study this biology and the important downstream (and potentially pathogenic) consequences when this normal regulation is lost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Cancer is the second most common chronic disease and cause of death among those ages 65 and older and 75% of the 22 million projected cancer survivors will be 65+ by 2030. Unfortunately, persistent racial/ethnic inequities in cancer survivorship are likely to increase with the growing number and proportion of older survivors from racial/ethnic minority groups and the absence of research groups integrating aging, disparities and cancer disciplines. The “Infrastructure for Research in Equity, Aging, Cancer and Health” (I-REACH) will bring together stakeholders and researchers to support career development and increase the diversity of the scientific workforce and generate knowledge to improve health and reduce health disparities in older minority cancer survivors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulating evidence indicate that a small subset of tumor cells readily adapt to different types of cellular stresses, including anticancer drugs, ultimately giving rise to tumors for which no effective treatments exist. IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Histomonas meleagridis is a unicellular parasite that causes severe morbidity and mortality in poultry populations, especially in turkeys, with mortality rates reaching 70-80%, but there are no drugs are available for preventing or treating histomonosis. Our research has revealed that H. meleagridis transitions into a cyst-like form, which serves as an intermediate stage to mediate infections among turkey poults, highlighting the potential of targeting the encystation pathway for innovative drug development to block parasite transmission. Our proposal aims to characterize the molecular mechanisms by which H. meleagridis parasites form cysts and transmit them between turkeys, to repurpose existing inhibitors used against other infectious diseases to mitigate histomonosis in turkey flocks, and to develop molecular genetic tools and generate transgenic H. meleagridis strains to advance research in this field.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Controlling Histomonas meleagridis transmission in turkey flocks

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Gene editing has the potential to improve the resilience, health and productivity of animals raised for food and thus the sustainability of a safe and healthy food supply. We propose to establish an Innovation Center focused on intentional genomic alterations (IGA) to advance the use of gene editing technologies in food animals while contributing data to support a science-based regulatory approach to the regulation of IGAs. The information gained through this Cooperative Agreement will lead to the safe implementation of gene editing in animals raised for food to ensure animal health and productivity and thus food security and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) affects approximately 16 million Americans, and is characterized by recurrent exacerbations that lead to 1.5 million Emergency Department visits and 700,000 hospitalizations annually. Pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) is a structured program of exercise and self- management support that has been proven to relieve shortness of breath and increase quality of life when initiated after an exacerbation, but unfortunately, few eligible patients participate. This project will compare the effectiveness of two novel strategies – one involving video narratives of other patients telling their story of how they overcame challenges and completed PR, the other involving telephonic peer coaching – to enhanced usual care, and to each other, at increasing patient participation in PR after an exacerbation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE UbiquiTx is pioneering a new class of computationally-designed mRNA therapeutics that encode peptide-guided protein degraders, known as ubiquibodies (uAbs), for potent and selective degradation of historically undruggable targets not addressable by conventional drugs. To further advance our platform, this Phase I STTR project seeks to design customized uAbs against β-catenin and CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein homologous protein (CHOP), two intracellular transcription factors that hold promise as drug targets for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), and other liver diseases. By accelerating the removal of these two key intracellular disease drivers through LNP-mediated delivery of mRNA encoding peptide-guided uAbs, these studies will provide important proof-of-concept for our unconventional approach to drugging the proteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cadmium is a near ubiquitous food contaminant that the general (non-occupational, non-smoking) population ingests at higher levels than the WHO determined provisional tolerable weekly intake. Cadmium is associated with impaired vision, learning challenges and behavioral disorders, with possible cascading effects on future generations. This proposal examines how cadmium exposure insults vision and genetic profiles leading to negative effects on learning, memory, and behavior in juveniles and across generations using zebrafish (Danio rerio) as a model, which supports NIEHS new initiative on Environmental Risks for Psychiatric Disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative For the brain to function it is essential that large numbers of neurons are interconnected in a highly precise manner, a process which is controlled by the patterns of genes expressed during brain development. Work of this grant focuses on a circuit of the Drosophila brain controlling navigation. We are analyzing connectivity within this circuit with digital connectomes, and use optogenetic tools to record and manipulate neuronal activity in order to develop concepts which are important to understand, and therapeutically manipulate, circuits formed by nerve cells in the human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular drivers and cellular interactions drive changes in cancer cell state that contribute to tumor growth and progression, but how these factors coordinatively drive tumorigenesis is not well defined. I propose to elucidate mechanisms of chromatin regulation and evasion of immune response by using innovative mouse models and functional genomics analyses. This work will provide novel insight into the principles of chromatin regulation and tumor heterogeneity that contribute to progression in lung and pancreas cancers, which may also be applicable to other cancer types.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: This proposal is to establish the Northern Pacific Global Health Leadership, Education, And Development for Early-career Researchers (NPGH LEADERs) Consortium – a research training program directed by the University of Washington in partnership with the Universities of Hawaii, Michigan and Minnesota with international partnerships in Cameroon, Ghana, India, Kenya, Liberia, Nepal, Peru, Thailand, and Uganda. The goal of this Consortium is to provide outstanding mentored research training to U.S. and LMIC post-doctoral and U.S. pre-doctoral trainees at international partner institutions in order to create the next generation of independent global health scientists and leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The singular goal of most spinal cord injury (SCI) research programs is to repair the injured spinal cord and restore locomotor function. Unfortunately, restoration of walking is a low priority for most SCI individuals. In addition to impaired mobility, SCI causes slow and steady pathological changes in organ systems throughout the body. Failure to recognize and treat multi-organ system pathology as a standard of care may explain why survival rates have not improved for SCI patients (relative to able-bodied individuals) over the past 30 years. Experiments in this proposal are designed to study SCI as a disease of the entire body and will yield novel data that will ultimately promote recovery of function and quality of life (QoL) after SCI.

PROJECT_TITLE: Overcoming Neurogenic “Meta-Inflammation” to Promote Recovery After Spinal Cord Injury

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Mitochondria are the site of essential cellular processes such as metabolism and apoptosis (controlled cell death), which are often misregulated in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases. Proper mitochondrial function depends on a robust quality control system to remove old, damaged, or mislocalized proteins. Here, I propose experiments to test how mitochondrial protein quality control systems function, which could lead to new therapeutic approaches to cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The DPPOS AD/ADRD project will address the overarching question: What are the determinants and the nature of cognitive impairment among persons with pre-diabetes (PreD) and type 2 diabetes (T2D), who are a high-risk group for cognitive impairment and represent a large fraction of the United States (US) population? This U19 proposal addresses the National Alzheimer’s Project Act goal to “prevent, halt, or reverse AD” in the high-risk group of persons with pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes, who represent over half of the population aged 60 years and older in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Most behavioral weight-loss interventions have had mixed outcomes, with interventions failing to make a substantial or persistent difference in racial/ethnic minority populations. This may be secondary to neglecting the influence of an individual’s social environment. The results of this feasibility randomized control trial will result in a multi-level intervention that targets individual and network-level barriers to weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Physical therapy is the first line of treatment for patients with low back pain (LBP) and has been shown to be a cost-effective method for improving pain and disability in patients with chronic LBP; however, despite this effectiveness, only 7-13% of patients go on to receive physical therapy services with patients in rural communities being especially limited to do lack of provider availability, transportation, and missed work time leading to greater rates of LBP-related disability and opioid consumption. With the rapid emergence of digital treatment approaches to physical therapy (i.e., telerehabilitation), access could be improved by reducing or eliminating many barriers that patients report; however, it is unclear how to appropriately incorporate digital treatment approaches into existing health care models. We propose a single-masked prospective randomized clinical trial conducted at a health system serving rural communities to determine the effectiveness of innovative risk-stratified telerehabilitation versus standard educational control for patients with chronic LBP that will match individual patients with specific physical therapy delivery (remote therapeutic monitoring; physical therapy telehealth visits; or psychologically informed physical therapy telehealth visits) based on their psychosocial risk of poor outcomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Influenza is a virus that causes respiratory disease and circulates annually, despite a vaccine, and due to antigenic shifts, influenza can also cause pandemic disease. This project career development program will provide training that allows a veterinary physician-scientist to develop an independent research career aimed at understanding in detail how human antibody therapy can be used to treat and prevent disease and transmission. This knowledge work will inform vaccine design, and the antibodies studied and animal models developed will feed directly into translatable drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: In response to severe respiratory infections like influenza and SARS-CoV-2, a mediator of inflammation called HMGB1 is released from dying cells and leads to the “cytokine storm” associated with disease progression. Our novel inducible platform produces an inhibitor of HMGB1 in response to inflammation that is expected to counteract disease and be broadly applicable against many different inflammatory agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because about 1 in 9 US adults aged 45 years and older reports some memory loss for commonly memorable information in everyday life. Clarifying how the brain typically finds things memorable will lead to more efficient diagnosis and intervention strategies for memory impairments, especially in aging and neurological disorders (e.g., dementia and Alzheimer’s). Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission that pertains to the discovery of fundamental knowledge about the nature of living systems to enhance health and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primate retina contains an incredible diversity of retinal circuits, the majority of which have not been characterized or integrated into models of primate vision. This project will use retinal physiology, circuit tracing and measures of behavior, all in the living macaque eye, to elucidate the roles of the rare retinal output neurons in primate vision, both in health and disease. The results will clarify the timeline of retinal degeneration following V1 stroke damage and the division of labor between the retina and the brain to inform techniques that seek to restore appropriate signals in the retinas of the blind.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Successful completion of the proposed experiments will characterize the role of astrocytic circadian clock in regulating synaptic rhythmicity and cognitive performance. There is a strong comorbidity between disruptions to the circadian cycle, and cognitive impairments, yet the mechanistic link is not well understood. We will examine how astrocytic molecular clock regulates time-of-day-dependent changes in synapse number and activity, determine the mechanisms controlling its function, and identify the rhythmic astrocytic factors that can be targeted to correct clock-related cognitive deficits.

This supplement will integrate fascia-specific MRI into the TARA platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall This application proposes the extension of our eye and pancreas Tissue Mapping Center at Vanderbilt University associated with the Human BioMolecular Atlas Program (HuBMAP). The mission of this Tissue Mapping Center is to build a platform of integrated technologies for imaging and molecular analysis that enables the construction of comprehensive 3-dimensional molecular atlases of the human eye and pancreas. Our proposal leverages the unique analytical and computational resources of the Mass Spectrometry Research Center and the VU- Biomolecular Multimodal Imaging Center at Vanderbilt University, the world-class clinical environments of the Vanderbilt University Medical Center, and the unique technical expertise at the Delft University of Technology to create a capability to characterize human tissues at a level of understanding unrivaled by current technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the last decade, the national alcohol impaired driving crash fatality rate has increased by 23% and the most recent data shows no evidence of a significant decline in the immediate future. Among driver age groups in alcohol impaired driving crashes, the 21-24y/o group is one of the most vulnerable and holds the highest proportion of alcohol impaired drivers involved in fatal crashes. Applying a policy innovation approach with the concept of an age-based reduce early risk exposure among young drivers that drink (i.e., reducing the BAC per se limit to ≥.05 from the current ≥.08 for drivers 21 through 24y/o) could yield significant reductions in alcohol impaired driving crash injury, disability, and death among drivers and their passengers while simultaneously improving the public’s safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are endosymbiotic organelles that have their own genome and perform many essential functions in eukaryotic cells, including ATP synthesis via oxidative phosphorylation. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations cause heritable respiratory chain deficiency and contribute to a wide spectrum of diseases in humans, including metabolic disease, neurodegeneration, and cancer. The proposed research will define how mtDNA synthesis is regulated at the chromosome, organelle and cellular levels in physiologically relevant cellular and invertebrate models, and how disruption of these processes impinges on mtDNA integrity, cellular homeostasis, and ultimately human health. This work is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that fosters fundamental basic cell biology discoveries that will directly lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets and therapies for the treatment of a wide array of human diseases.
