PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol is the top substance used by US emerging adults under the legal drinking age (underage emerging adults; U-EA; ages 18-19). We respond to PAR-21-280 and propose to use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to disaggregate the interaction between U-EA brain response among group MI participants (peer dyads) in the underexamined, but widely-utilized group MI context. In this study, we will examine the nature of peer-peer dyadic exchanges in the youth brain during group MI interventions (Aim 1) and predictors of behavior change: prospective relationships between youth brain response and behavior change in the novel context of group MI (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Over 700,000 Americans receive invasive mechanical ventilation in an ICU each year. Many of these patients do not receive evidence-based therapies proven to save lives, leading to preventable morbidity and mortality. Innovative strategies to overcome the barriers to evidence-based practice and speed knowledge translation in the ICU are urgently needed. By developing novel approaches for knowledge translation in acute respiratory failure, this research program will help new treatments reach the bedside more quickly, leading to improved outcomes for critically ill patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide and obesity is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis and other metabolic diseases. My exciting data show that weight loss induced by caloric- restriction promotes resolution and remission of atherosclerosis and I propose to study the underlying mechanisms. My studies will uncover novel pathways responsible for the concomitant resolution of obesity and atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE  Despite the legalization of cannabis in multiple states (it is only fully illegal in 6), there are still no federal regulations for health warnings on cannabis products in the U.S. The fact that cannabis has adverse and therapeutic outcomes has contributed to an environment where substantial proportions of U.S. consumers both over- and under-estimate the health risks of cannabis. This project will assess adult cannabis consumers’ reactions to draft warning labels, experimentally determine how attributes of cannabis warning labels affect consumers’ emotions and perceived risks, and then develop and test our enhanced warning labels against existing labels to determine how label exposure influences perceived risk, health beliefs, and higher-risk cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Human genome engineering has widely anticipated promise as a healthcare strategy, but technologies in development are unlikely to safely or efficiently introduce a gene into the human genome. Starkly missing from transgene introduction strategies is an approach based on what is already quite successful across eukaryotic evolution: gene insertion by synthesis of an RNA-templated complementary DNA (cDNA). The evolutionary success of RNA template-specific, DNA site-specific LINE/non-LTR retroelement insertion begs to be engineered to develop a transgene introduction technology for human gene therapy.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE  KRAS mutations represent one of the most frequently recurrent initiating events in lung cancer. We identified protein kinase C epsilon (PKCe) as an essential player in KRAS- and carcinogen-mediated lung tumor initiation, and as an important regulator of signaling that promotes lung cancer cell motility and invasion. In this application we will investigate the molecular basis of the permissive role for PKCe in oncogenic KRAS-mediated lung tumor development and identify downstream effectors responsible for PKCe-driven lung tumorigenesis and metastatic phenotypes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Chronic visceral pain is a debilitating condition which lacks effective clinical management and represents a major unmet medical problem, which is caused by a lack of understanding of the basic mechanisms. The current proposal aims to identify unique spinal cord dorsal horn neurons and circuits involved in the pathogenesis of visceral pain in the hopes of finding novel drug targets for treating chronic visceral pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Exposure to environmental agents can induce abnormal skeletal development posing lifelong implications for the patient’s health. This study is significant because it will reveal a novel mechanism whereby environmental toxicants influence osteoblast differentiation through alterations in microRNA expression. Through this, this proposal is relevant to the mission of NIH to increase understanding of how the environment affects biological processes to advance disease diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and ultimately support healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Somatic mutations accumulated with aging and/or in response to environmental insult and chronic inflammation can confer a selective advantage leading to clonal expansion in hematopoietic stem cells, a phenomenon termed 'Clonal Hematopoiesis of Indeterminate Potential' (CHIP). CHIP has been associated with a selective range of non-hematopoietic conditions, including coronary artery disease, stroke, heart failure, venous thromboembolism, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic liver diseases, and osteoporosis, yet the molecular mechanisms by which CHIP specifically promotes these diseases remain largely unknown. I will leverage large-scale multi-omics data to molecularly connect CHIP with the development of associated diseases and identify the mechanisms underlying CHIP-associated disease risks and thus prioritize therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost all colorectal cancers (CRCs) have mutations that activate oncogenic Wnt/β-catenin signaling, but there are no known effective therapies targeting this pathway, and this disease remains the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the US. We found that mutations that activate Wnt signaling upstream of GSK3 induce profound sensitization to asparaginase in CRC. We propose here to investigate the molecular mechanisms through which Wnt signaling induces asparaginase hypersensitivity, which is expected to shed fundamental insights into the cellular response to amino acid starvation and its interaction with Wnt signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The antileukemic drug asparaginase is a central component of curative therapy for several acute leukemias, but the development of resistance is a major clinical problem with a poor prognosis. We found that inhibition of the kinase GSK3α induces asparaginase sensitization in several drug-resistant subtypes of acute leukemia. We propose to investigate the biology underlying this potent therapeutic interaction, which is expected to provide fundamental insights into the amino acid starvation response, and allow its rational therapeutic exploitation for maximal clinical benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteocytes serve as the major orchestrator of skeletal metabolism and many pathologic or disease conditions can now be ascribed to disrupted osteocyte functions. This proposal describes an innovative and comprehensive approach to investigate the osteocytic role of the transcription factor SP7. Ultimately, the long-term goal of this study is to determine not only how osteocyte-enriched genes function in bone disease, but also to enable the development of next generation therapeutics for skeletal diseases that target osteocyte development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NICHD established the Neonatal Research Network (NRN) to investigate persistent unanswered questions regarding the safety and efficacy of treatment and management strategies for newborn infants. RTI, as the NRN Data Coordinating Center (DCC) since 1988, is uniquely positioned to provide support to the Feeding in Premature Infants Working Group and will pull from a highly experienced bench of DCC coordinators who are up-to-date on the latest advances in neonatal research. RTI, as the NRN DCC, will provide support to the Feeding in Premature Infants Working Group and will draft a report on behalf of the Working Group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain Healthy will engage students from diverse backgrounds in citizen science investigations of their own brain health and wellness, which is particularly relevant given COVID-related increased concern about mental health and well-being. The program will expose students to data science (a new area of major SEPA interest) and topics such as brain plasticity and stress management (which are tightly related to NIH-funded research) and will allow students to explore the relations between healthy lifestyle practices (e.g., physical exercise) and cognitive/affective measures. Through this experience, students will not only increase their conceptual understanding of the brain basis of healthy lifestyle choices, but they will also acquire important and widely applicable data analytic and communication practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Cytopathology plays a critical role in the assessment of fine needle aspiration biopsies (FNAB) of thyroid nodules that may harbor cancers. This expertise is a scarce resource in Low and Middle Income Countries (LMIC). This project will tailor an existing machine learning algorithm for use in LMIC, specifically Tanzania and Vietnam, in order to have a future protocol in which expert cytopathology can be immediately accessible using existing equipment and mobile devices. This will be done through implementation of a protocol to analyze FNAB using a machine learning algorithm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of disability and death among U.S. older adults and represents an enormous public health burden. Although CVD risk assessment is recommended as the foundation to primary prevention and guiding treatment decisions, the current tool for risk assessment performs poorly in older adults and among disadvantaged population groups. We propose to address these limitations by incorporating changes in risk factors over time and integrating social determinants of health to improve CVD risk-prediction and its translation to disease prevention in U.S. older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a chronic and relapsing brain disease that is characterized by loss of control over opioid use, and affects over 2 million Americans causing one overdose death every 20 minutes. Further research is urgently needed to better understand the mechanisms that contribute to ongoing illicit opioid use. The Collaboration Linking Opioid Use Disorder and Sleep (“CLOUDS”) Study examines sleep and circadian mechanisms that may contribute to OUD and proposes to fulfill a critical step towards identifying novel treatments that may lead to improved outcomes for patients with OUD.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated mucosal trafficking and activation of neutrophils in the intestine are major factors contributing to pathobiology of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The goal of this application is to determine how neutrophil CD45 can be selectively targeted to down regulate excessive neutrophil migration and effector functions during intestinal inflammation. Results from these studies will provide ideas for new targeted therapies to reduce pathological inflammation and improve quality of life for individuals with IBD and other mucosal inflammatory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance our capability to invent therapeutics and subsequently prepare these medicines on large-scale. Inspired by Nature’s catalyst, we develop ideal, environmentally friendly, and powerful ways to transform simple building blocks (aldehydes, alkenes, and alkynes) into architectures relevant to medicine. Our expertise in molecular design and synthesis will also be applied to address challenges at the interface of chemical theory, fluorescent microscopy, and drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed “Sjögren’s Team for Accelerating Medicines Partnership (STAMP)” is strategically positioned to apply cutting-edge technologies to interrogate the tissue and systems biology of Sjögren’s disease (SjD) to better understand 1) the pathogenesis of SjD and identify therapeutic targets, and new biomarkers; and 2) disease mechanisms inherent to progression of SjD from non-SjD to SjD, and from “early SjD” to “advanced SjD”. To achieve these goals, we plan to develop a 5-year scientific research agenda, and design standardized clinical research protocols to recruit, enroll, phenotype, and collect relevant biospecimens from, observational cohorts of individuals with SjD and controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This project aims to understand how genetic factors increase the risk for juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), one of the most common chronic disease conditions in children. In this study, we will examine how genetic variants alter a class of genome regulators called enhancers, which are like rheostats that allow cells to turn genes up or down depending on the circumstances. We will then identify genes that are affected by altered enhancers, an important step toward developing new therapies and improving outcome for children with this disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE The Integrated Networks of Scholars in Global Health Research Training (INSIGHT) consortium formed between the University of Alabama at Birmingham, the Baylor College of Medicine, the University of Maryland Baltimore, and the University of Pittsburgh supports training for the next generation of global health scholars from the US and low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) through mentored research experiences at 24 established partner LMIC institutions across 19 countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Strong emphases are on a broad range of global health research areas, including combatting the global HIV epidemic and associated co-morbidities, emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases, and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SUMMARY (Parent)  The Overarching Aim of the Northwestern HeartShare Data Translation Center (DTC) is to provide overall management and oversight for HeartShare, including coordination and communication across all subsections and cores of the program, and with the 4 HeartShare Clinical Centers (CCs). The DTC will need to ensure timely completion of the retrospective (first 2 years) and prospective (all 5 years) components of HeartShare. In our application, we demonstrate the ability and prior experience of our multi-PI team and core leaders in the conduct and leadership of large-scale, multi-center studies, particularly in the realms of HFpEF, EHR-based investigation, deep phenotyping, and biorepositories. We also highlight our experience as liaisons/translators among clinical researchers, clinicians, and data scientists; expertise in phenotype ontology and harmonization; and collaboration with the University of Vermont biorepository, which has extensive experience in this realm. For both the retrospective and prospective HeartShare components, the Northwestern DTC will leverage its considerable experience in: (1) cohorts and trials that have data on adjudicated HFpEF patients, and (2) its leadership and track record as the top enroller in HFpEF trials/studies to ensure optimal recruitment by the HeartShare CCs. We will also leverage our expertise in HFpEF, data coordination/management, BioData Catalyst, electronic health record-based research, biostatistics, data science, machine learning, multi-omics, human-computer interaction, and mobile health data monitoring to successfully execute the HeartShare program and meet The HeartShare DTC goals of providing a rich resource to the research community and advancing the science of next-generation phenomics to identify HFpEF subtypes and therapeutic targets. Our HeartShare DTC will carry out each of its 4 primary responsibilities. (1) The Administrative and Outreach Core will oversee HeartShare program operations, research skills development, and capitation to CCs for deep phenotyping costs; support a call center to follow patient outcomes; and promote rapid and broad data-sharing of clinical and molecular data. (2) The Data Portal Core will serve as the primary access point (via a web-based interface) and coordinating center for all HeartShare data; and to develop an interactive patient-facing web-based interface for remote consent, completion of forms, and collection of mobile health data using BioData Catalyst tools. (3) The Data Management Core will oversee and perform data quality, integration and harmonization of various data types; performance of advanced analytics; coordination of biospecimen and imaging biorepositories; and integration with TOPMed for omics analyses. (4) The Cohort Core will aggregate data on HF patients from completed epidemiology cohorts and HF trials and will combine data with further bioprofiling of existing samples to allow discovery/validation of novel targets. PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Northwestern HeartShare Data Translation Center will provide overall management and oversight of the HeartShare program via 4 cores, including an Administrative/Outreach, Data Portal, Data Management, and Cohort cores. By providing a diverse investigative team and complementary areas of expertise, the HeartShare Data Translation Center will achieve the primary goals of HeartShare: (1) to develop a rich resource for the research community for the detailed study of heart failure; and (2) to advance the science of identifying novel heart failure subtypes to promote a tailored, precision medicine approach to heart failure patients in order to reduce morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine abnormality in women in the U.S. and is characterized by both reproductive (anovulation and androgen excess) and metabolic dysfunction (insulin resistance). PCOS lacks a simple, safe and effective treatment for women of all ages and all weights. Recently a dietary supplement, inositol, has been used widely to treat women with PCOS. However there are no well- designed trials to address the risk/benefit ratio and identify the mechanism of action. In this study we are actively conducting a three month double blind (of both patients and investigators) randomized controlled trial of inositol supplementation compared to placebo. Our primary outcome is, women with PCOS who receive inositol supplementation will have a significantly greater reduction in serum total testosterone than women on placebo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The overall objective of the proposed project is to study the biological basis of violent juvenile aggression in a novel animal model. This work has implications for public health as experiences of aggression have long-lasting individual and societal consequences and disorders with high co-morbidity of aggressive behavior are on the rise, but a tractable model system is currently lacking. Research outcomes will have a significant positive impact by illuminating causes, consequences, and potential treatments targets for violent aggression among the youngest members of our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it interrogates mechanisms of CD4+ T cell dysregulation and of impaired vaccine response in people with Down syndrome. This knowledge would establish the foundation to identify therapies to mitigate immune aging and impaired vaccine response in people, both with and without Down syndrome, with likely utility across a broad spectrum of immune-related conditions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission pertaining to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Immune, malignant, vascular, and other cells present in tumors are not randomly distributed, but are organized into different neighborhoods typified by specific, recurrent sets of multicellular interactions. This research proposal explores how a recently discovered, clinically significant multicellular network shapes the behavior of cancer-fighting T cells. By understanding and manipulating this cellular neighborhood, we may be able to mold T cells to optimally combat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is prevalent, debilitating, and costly, and maternal depression is one of the most established risk factors of depression in offspring; however, the genetic and environmental risk factors tied to intergenerational risk are complex and largely unspecified. I will conduct a multimodal, dyadic research design to examine a potential neurobehavioral pathway from depression in mothers to the development of increased depression risk in young children. This study has relevance for identifying children at greatest risk for depression development according to neural indicators and proposing a behavioral target for intervention in mother−child processes in order to mitigate risk.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Neurobehavioral markers of positive valence systems in mothers with depression and young offspring
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Biobehavioral Mechanisms of Emotion, Stress and Health Study Section[MESH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Meiosis is a specialized set of cell divisions that generate male (sperm) and female (egg) gametes. In females, meiosis is associated with high rates of chromosome segregation errors, which lead to miscarriage, infertility, and developmental disorders such as Down’s syndrome. This project uses mouse oocytes as a model system to understand the basic molecular mechanisms that regulate female meiosis, thereby shedding a light on why this process is notoriously error prone.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The UCLA-South Africa Sustainable Academic Capacity Building for Excellence in Research Training (SACERT) builds on 14 years of research training of South African early career investigators and academic communities on chronic stress and non-communicable chronic mental health disorders including substance abuse, depression, and posttraumatic stress disorder across the life course. As an international collaboration between UCLA and 12 institutions in South Africa, including University of Cape Town, Human Sciences Research Council, Stellenbosch University, and Walter Sisulu University, SACERT’s public health mission is to: 1) increase the number of well-trained South African researchers and mentors in chronic stress and non- communicable chronic mental health; 2) translate research findings into culturally congruent substance abuse and mental health treatment interventions and programs; and 3) facilitate the building of sustainable community clinical and research capacity and university infrastructure that benefits South African people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) has increased substantially, and it is associated with both short- and long-term adverse outcomes for both women and their children. The strategies used for GDM rely on diagnosis and treatment in the third trimester, but these have not consistently reduced or eliminated the adverse outcomes that occur. Therefore, there is a vital need to develop novel strategies, including earlier diagnosis and better ascertainment of blood sugar profiles, that predict adverse outcomes related to dysglycemia, which will result in better treatment approaches and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At Stanford over the last decade, the Gurtner group has used NIDDK funding to identify the best treatment plans to improve blood flow, decrease blood glucose, and enhance the body's ability to heal wounds and prevent amputations. With Dr. Gurtner recently assuming the position of Chair of Surgery at the University of Arizona (UArizona) College of Medicine-Tucson, the entire team has moved and worked tirelessly to seamlessly transfer all the existing Diabetic Foot Consortium (DFC) studies to UArizona. In this proposal, we will continue these important studies at UArizona to collect a large range of samples from a diverse patient population to improve biomarker identification and standard of care efforts for DFUs, as well as demonstrate our potential for the addition of various satellite sites throughout the Southwest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are many patients of a-thalassemia, current therapies are insufficient for many of them and there are very few studies on a-thalassemia; in addition, no severe mouse models are available to study this disease and to test new therapies. Our goals are to generate new mouse models to investigate this understudied disease and to test if a newly generated lentiviral vector that expresses the human a-globin gene can correct mice affected by severe forms of a-thalassemia. Our proposed work will address these knowledge gaps by developing, characterizing, and validating mouse models and gene therapy vectors for treating severe a-thalassemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE The ultimate goal of this proposal is to uncover how pre-mRNA splicing and trafficking through nuclear speckles is controlled by the kinase TAO2, and why TAO2 is required for successful Influenza virus (IAV) replication. This work will have implications not only for viral infections but also for general mechanisms of RNA splicing and nuclear speckle function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narratives The goal of this proposal is to determine the role of estrogen and its receptors (estrogen receptor 1 and G protein coupled estrogen receptor 1) in regulating eye pressure by affecting the different parts in the anterior chamber of the eye. Eye pressure is the primary and only treatable risk factor with glaucoma patients in the clinic. The successful completion of this project will help uncover critical information on the specific roles of estrogen and its signaling pathways in regulating eye pressure and identify new treatment targets to lower eye pressure more effectively in glaucoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This MIRA proposal will develop sampling algorithms at the interface of statistical mechanics and artificial intelligence to probe mechanisms for rare event processes, such as drug unbinding and conformational change in drug targets. These algorithms will be used to guide mechanistically driven design of inhibitors of Src, Abl kinases and PreQ1 riboswitches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an epidemic of chronic kidney disease in Central America and mortality rates are highest in El Salvador and Nicaragua. This Field Epidemiology Site will recruit 800 residents of the most affected regions of each country including ~400 people with low kidney function at baseline, and ~400 people with high or healthy kidney function at baseline, including men and women. We will follow them for three years to examine kidney function and disease progression over time, and exposure to multiple environmental, social, behavioral and occupational risk factors as part of the Chronic Kidney Diseases of UnceRtain Etiology (CKDu) in Agricultural Communities (CURE) Research Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There is accumulating evidence showing that the circadian system plays a critical role in many physical activity-related pathways and regulates the diurnal variations in the cardiometabolic responses to physical activity. This raises the question whether timing may modulate the adaptive responses of physical activity, and can thus be used to enhance the health benefits of physical activity. Here, we aim to test the relationship between timing of physical activity and cardiometabolic outcomes in humans, with the hope of providing mechanistic insights that may assist in the design of lifestyle interventions to improve the efficacy of physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Diabetic retinopathy is the leading cause of blindness in working-age adults with more than 190 million worldwide projected to be affected by 2030. This project will develop a computer model to predict initiation and progression of diabetic retinopathy based on changes in blood flow in retinal vessels that are caused by changes in the properties of blood cells and vessel structure due to their prolonged exposure to diabetic conditions. The detailed and accurate prediction from this model may provide novel insights on blood flow-mediated pathogenesis of retinopathy, and reliable metrics for early disease detection, thereby directly benefiting clinical diagnosis and treatment. An Administrative Supplement is requested to purchase a high-performance computing system to perform the modeling study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently shown that T cells in the placental villi are active and inflammatory during intraamniotic inflammation, a process commonly associated with preterm birth. In this grant application, we will use our combined expertise in mucosal immunology (L. Konnikova), placental biology (V. Abrahams, S. Guller), placental pathology (R. Morotti) and bioinformatics (G. Tseng) to uncover placental villi T cell abnormalities in preterm births. We will use our current biorepository and ongoing collection of placental specimens to: (1) delineate T cell surface phenotypes, anatomic localization, activation mechanisms, and transcription, and TCR profiles unique to preterm placental villi and (2) interrogate the downstream effects of T cell activation on surrounding trophoblast cells as a potential mediator of preterm labor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE PTP1B, a non-receptor–type oncogenic PTP, also known as PTPN1, is involved in growth factor signaling. The PTP1B gene is frequently amplified in ovarian, gastric, prostate, and breast cancers and correlates with poor prognosis. However, despite the attractiveness of PTP1B as a therapeutic target, the development of drug-like inhibitors of this enzyme has proven difficult, primarily due to low cell permeability and a lack of selectivity towards other PTPs. The goal of this proposal is to develop charge neutral inhibitors that specifically target the oxidized form of PTP1B (PTP1B- ox), which exists principally in the disease state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Natural products from bacteria, fungi, and plants have long been a rich source of therapeutically relevant molecules, but the relationship between natural product structure and activity is not fully understood, hindering our ability to further optimize natural products for therapeutic use. Machine learning can be used to develop models that explain trends in data and make predictions for new data points. In this work we will apply machine learning to understand structure-activity relationships in natural products, design biosynthetic gene clusters to improve our ability to biosynthesize natural product analogs, and repurpose natural products as protein- protein interaction inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune-mediated neurological disorder characterized by the accumulation of lesions laden with inflammatory microglia in the central nervous system (CNS), which drive demyelination and impede the remyelination process. This project will investigate a strategy to enhance remyelination by genetically modifying microglial cells in demyelinated lesions towards a pro-regenerative state. The results of this study will advance our understanding of the immunoregulatory mechanisms governing remyelination, which could have implications for the development of pharmacological therapies aimed at improving remyelination in individuals with MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  N6-methyladenosine (m6A) represents the most abundant internal modification of mRNA, and while we now have a reasonable understanding of the biochemical machinery that places this epitranscriptomic mark, we are still in the infancy of understanding its biological importance in vivo. Recent efforts point to the nervous system as being especially sensitive to m6A-mediated gene regulation. This project will integrate powerful genetic, genomic, biochemical, and electrophysiological tools available in the Drosophila system to determine how m6A regulates synaptic activity at the neuromuscular junction, and dissect multiple molecular mechanisms by which m6A imparts regulatory impacts in the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy is a significant public health issue, due to its high economic burden, increased death rate in patients, and the inadequacy of current therapeutics to control seizures in up to a third of patients. Thus, new approaches are needed for the development of innovative, more effective treatments, including preclinical models based on animals that recapitulate the complex etiology of major human epilepsy syndromes. Our study is relevant to NIH’s mission because the genetic characterization of baboon epilepsy and development of in vitro cerebral organoid systems analogous to those used in human studies provides a platform for testing of new therapies that can be easily translated using a naturally occurring primate model of epilepsy, reducing clinical attrition and improving disease outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple system atrophy is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by the abnormal accumulation of the protein alpha-synuclein in oligodendrocytes accompanied by inflammation and neuron loss in the brain. The treatment and development of therapeutics is limited due to a gap in knowledge of mechanisms that mediate this neurodegenerative process. The goal of this project is to investigate the contribution of brain- resident and peripheral immune cells in initiating and sustaining inflammation, and target these cells as a novel way of blocking disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thus far, it is unclear whether the underlying cause of chronic metabolic complications after SCI may be linked to adipose tissue dysfunction. Also unknown are the cellular and molecular mechanisms that cause or contribute to pathophysiological changes in white adipose tissue (WAT) after SCI. This study proposes and aims to test the hypothesis that aberrant sensory plasticity causes maladaptive changes in WAT and vascular function associated with chronic metabolic complications and insulin resistance after SCI, thereby providing novel molecular targets that can be manipulated for therapeutic gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This randomized clinical trial tests how telehealth technology can positively affect informal caregivers and patients living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. The project will gather data over time to measure the impact of our evidence-based Brain CareNotes mobile telehealth app on informal caregiver burden and patients’ behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, in a diverse Indiana-wide sample.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Falls (i) are common, (ii) directly injure or kill many Americans each year, and (iii) increase exponentially as we age. While many factors contribute to falls, we focus on vestibular degradation because new data show that age- related increases in vestibular thresholds mediate (“explain”) nearly half of age-related balance declines; related findings have led to estimates that up to 150,000 Americans might die each year due to sub-optimal vestibular function, including sub-clinical age-related vestibular declines. As crucial steps to reduce age-related falls, we propose extensive human testing designed to develop: (a) targeted vestibular screening tests by quantifying impacts of vestibular declines on age-related balance declines and falls and (b) a potential intervention designed to improve vestibular precision, which could also improve balance and reduce falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension affects half of American adults but poses an especially severe burden on African Americans. Understanding and eliminating disparities in hypertension and related social determinants of health is a national research priority identified in NHLBI’s Strategic Vision. This project will leverage unique opportunities in spatial epidemiology to quantify the fraction of hypertension disparities that can be eliminated by addressing disparities in geographic areas’ socioeconomic characteristics and structural environmental resources.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interactions between the brain’s neurons and glia play important roles in normal and pathological neurological processes. Thus, gaining a better understanding the brain’s glia, and, in particular, the neuron-glia interactions, will have wide-ranging implications for human health. In this application, we describe projects to develop novel chemical tools that will enable visualization and manipulation of glia and neuron-glia interactions that will further our understanding of their roles in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoclasts are cells that break down bone during normal growth and repair, playing a significant role in bone destructive diseases like osteoporosis, periodontal disease, cancer, and arthritis. This project aims to determine if lysine-specific demethylase 1 (LSD1), a protein that regulates osteoclast formation by removing methyl groups from histones, inhibits osteoclast formation and activity. Understanding the molecular mechanisms governing the activity of LSD1 may lead to development of pharmaceutical treatments for diseases associated with increased bone resorption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL The University of Miami’s Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center (Sylvester), the only NCI-designated cancer center in South Florida, is a source of discovery and innovation in cancer research, effective and inclusive approaches to education and training, novel community outreach and engagement activities for the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer, and hope for residents of its uniquely diverse catchment area. Focused on catchment area-relevant research, Sylvester’s four Research Programs span the spectrum of basic, clinical, translational, and population science research to reduce the human burden from cancer in the community the center serves. Sylvester leaders, clinicians and researchers work collaboratively to create a culture and environment that advances diversity, equity, and inclusion, and uses technologically advanced and culturally sensitive approaches to develop, evaluate, and implement novel treatments and effective interventional strategies that will sustainably and favorably impact cancer outcomes in South Florida and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The central research mission of our lab is to uncover the core principles underlying the assembly heterochromatin, a central gene-repressive element in the genome. Heterochromatin assembly heritably partitions the genome into active and inactive regions and in its normal state, this process drives cellular differentiation, while when misregulated, underlies a variety of diseases, including several cancers. We propose an integrative approach to define central cellular and biochemical mechanisms of dynamic heterochromatin assembly, ranging from single molecule biophysical to real-time single-cell measurements, which will reveal crucial intervention points for tuning this reaction in disease treatment, regenerative medicine, and synthetic biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Impairment of information processing is a frequent consequence of stroke. Several interventions have been developed to address this impairment but the transfer of gains made in the treatment setting to everyday life and the retention of these gains is limited. The proposed research is designed to begin the process of evaluating a Transfer Package of behavioral techniques designed to result in: 1) transfer of gains achieved in the treatment setting to everyday life, and 2) result in retention of the real-world gains without decrement for at least 1 year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This supplement proposal is designed to address specific gaps in resources and staffing needed to meet key objectives of the HEALthy Brain and Child Development (HBCD) Study in the current funding cycle. The specific needs that will be filled by this proposal are expansion, careful evaluation, and improvement of the Study Navigator Program; improved efficiency and oversight of the Spanish Language and Culture component of the study; and resources targeted to strategically support recruitment opportunities at HBCD sites to meet and accelerate progress toward recruitment objectives. The aims of this proposal will be carried out by the HBCD Administrative Core.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. This project will test the transformative hypothesis that dysregulated DNA rereplication in response to cellular stress contributes to the development of Trisomy 21 (T21) and subsequent pathophysiology of Down syndrome (DS). This project arises from the observation the interferon receptor cluster encoded on chromosome 21 undergoes DNA rereplication and targeted transient site-specific gene amplification in response to viral infection in healthy cells; however, this process is impaired in T21 cells. To test our hypothesis, we will employ a combination of human and mouse culture models and a mouse in vitro fertilization model to define the extent of DNA rereplication dysregulation in T21 and how DNA rereplication could contribute to the development of T21 and comorbidities associated with DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Liver cirrhosis is a serious chronic condition that leads to liver cancer and death. Prevention of complications of cirrhosis is key as once complications arise, the only medically viable option for improved survival is liver transplantation. The mechanisms of disease progression, clinical risks, and therapies to prevent progression are important to reducing cirrhosis burden. The Liver Cirrhosis Network and its proposed studies will enhance understanding of strategies important to prevention of cirrhosis progression including the utility of a commonly prescribed lipid lowering medication, statin, that if beneficial will translate into improved patient care and reduction of the cirrhosis disease complication burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variation is now understood to contribute to complex disease through disruption of gene regulatory networks. However, our limited understanding of the nature of these networks makes it difficult to find mechanistic links between the genome and disease. In this proposal we will combine perturbation-response data with sophisticated causal inference algorithms to build large-scale networks integrating gene expression with complex traits, enabling improved understanding of the mechanisms underlying disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Hospital-Based Violence Intervention Programs (HVIPs) affiliated with trauma centers in the US focus on individual behavior modification for a reduction in re-victimization. There is a lack of reproducible evidence that has demonstrated effectiveness, given the exclusion of addressing inequities in the Social and Structural Determinants of Health (SSDOH), often the root cause of violent injury and preventable homicide. We propose the creation of a novel Medical-Legal Trauma Partnership to offer legal support to improve the SSDOH, reduce stress, improve the health-related quality of life in patients, families and HVIP providers alike while collaborating with the CLIF-VP Coordinating Center for broad trauma center distribution for public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research and career development plans seek to investigate maladaptive avoidance learning as the principal mechanism of alcohol use disorders (AUD), a condition suffered by 15 million adults in the United States alone. Avoidance learning is complex, involving multiple neural, physiological, behavioral, and psychological processes, and currently under-explored as a pathophysiological pathway to AUD. The study proposes to directly examine these processes and identify the risk factors for the maintenance and relapse of AUD, thus potentially offering implications for the diagnosis, treatment, and ultimately the prevention of alcoholism.

PHR: Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation (CDGs) are rare diseases of glycosylation pathways with few therapeutic options. CDGs can cause developmental delay, seizures, or early death. This research will better define the mechanisms of these diseases and identify potential therapeutics using disease modelling, genetic perturbation, and a repurposed drug screen.

We will also investigate whether atorvastatin is an effective treatment for cirrhosis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to human health because patients with cirrhosis of the liver are at risk of liver disease progression, liver cancers and death, and treatments as well as the ability to identify patients at the highest risk of complications are lacking. In this application to be a clinical center in the Liver Cirrhosis Network, we propose to develop a prospective cohort to identify new ways to determine the risk of disease progression in patients with cirrhosis, and to test whether the medications pravastatin or alirocumab decrease this risk. The execution of these studies collaboratively throughout the Liver Cirrhosis Network will be crucial to understanding how patients with liver disease progress and how we can improve outcomes in this population in need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Komor – Project Narrative – “Development and Application of New Genome Editing Tools for the Functional Investigation of Genetic Variants of Uncertain Significance”  Our inability to interpret the clinical consequences of genetic variants discovered by sequencing remains a critical obstacle to the progress of precision medicine: out of the 4.6 million missense variants identified in the Genome Aggregation Database, over half are admitted to be variants of uncertain significance (VUS). New methods capable of interpreting VUS would not only enhance the efficacy of current therapies by better informing patient selection strategies, but also accelerate the development of new approaches to combat diseases with a genetic component. Here we propose the development of new genome editing tools and platforms that will allow researchers to functionally interrogate thousands of VUS individually, in combination, and in aggregate, to produce clinically-relevant information on how genetic variations cause human disease.

PHR: As one of the largest hospital systems nationally with a consistent referral pattern of patients with cirrhosis, we propose to be a part of the Liver Cirrhosis Network. We will establish a longitudinal cohort of cirrhotic patients with and without human immunodeficiency virus infection to enhance our mechanistic understanding of progression of disease, development of complications and predictors of clinical outcomes. We will also participate in a randomized placebo controlled trial to evaluate the benefits/safety of simvastatin in cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mechanical properties and forces the body are often modulated during disease initiation and progression. However, little is known about the response of immune cells to these mechanical cues, particularly at the tissue- length scale, and even in normal physiological settings. Establishing an omics-based understanding of functional immunological changes in response to mechanical perturbations will broaden our knowledge of “mechano- immunology” – a burgeoning subfield in basic biomedical sciences that in the near future will reveal new pathophysiological insights and targetable vulnerabilities for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Busy hospital settings and information overload from the electronic health record (EHR) contribute to decisional shortcuts and biases by clinicians that lead to missed opportunities for timely and accurate diagnoses. The proposal aims to develop novel clinical natural language processing (NLP) models that learn and integrate multi- modal EHR data, conduct reasoning over a large-scale medical knowledge base, and test them in a clinical decision support system to mitigate diagnostic error. Completion of the aims will inform the development of NLP- driven clinical decision support tools that generate accurate diagnoses to overcome provider heuristics and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE We are proposing to establish the Michigan Cancer and Research on the Environment Study (MI- CARES) which will include 100,000 participants aged 25-44 from Black, Hispanic, Middle Eastern and North African, and White racial/ethnic groups who reside in six environmental injustice hotspots in the state as there is an urgent need to fully understand the association between environmental exposures and cancer among understudied populations. We will study the impact of environmental exposures that are questionnaire-reported (e.g., personal care product use), proximity/model-based (e.g., air pollution and PFAS), and perinatal from linkage with birth records on inflammation measures (e.g., body mass index) as intermediate cancer markers in the entire cohort. We will also study laboratory-measured exposures (xenobiotics, PFAS, metals) and intermediate cancer biomarkers (cellular aging, immune function, inflammation, and metabolic pathway alteration) in a sub-cohort of cancer-free participants (n=1,000) and using a nested case- control design for those who develop cancer (n=250 cases and 250 controls).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Substance abuse disorders including opioid dependence are characterized by an imbalance between the gen- eration and detoxification of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the brain. In turn, ROS react with cysteine residues and these stress-related modifications often trigger changes in protein structure and function. The research pro- posed here develops and applies an innovative new chemoproteomics approach that will furnish a global portrait S-sulfenated (oxidized) cysteine ligandability in cell-based model of mu opioid receptor (MOR) signaling. The discovery of small molecules that bind to S-sulfenated (oxidized) cysteines in biological targets relevant to MOR signaling should serve as a rich resource for chemical probes and ultimately therapeutics to treat addiction and substance use disorders.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Nucleophile-Fragment Screening for Site-Specific Covalent Ligand Discovery in Opioid Receptor Signaling
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Chemical Biology and Probes Study Section[CBP]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The advent of successful gene therapy for certain retinal disorders and our extensive knowledge of the dozens of genes involved in hereditary hearing loss, together raise hope that gene therapy can be used to treat genetic forms of hearing loss. For instance mutations in the PCDH15 gene cause Usher syndrome type 1F, a devastating deafness, blindness and balance disorder. While we and others have achieved success in mouse models using gene therapy for short genes that will fit in adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors, PCDH15 is a long gene that does not fit into AAV; thus we propose to engineer short “mini-PCDH15” proteins, to test rescue of hearing and balance in mice, and to test localization and toxicity in nonhuman primates.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development of Gene Therapy for Hereditary Deafness using Rational Protein Engineering

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We will study the impact of high and chronic pesticide exposures in a rural environment on the gut microbiome of Parkinson’s disease (PD) patients, their household members and healthy community controls and its contributions to progression of PD. This research will be highly efficient due to our access to an existing cohort of PD patients and unaffected community controls - who live in a heavily agriculturally pesticide exposed area of California – and a network of rural health care providers. Our research may discovery novel etiological pathways for pesticide action through the microbiome, propose interventions to prevent PD progression, and change public policy and pesticide regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The primary objective of the proposed project is to develop a saliva-based biosensor by integrating research advances in sensing elements, machine learning, data analysis, microfluidics and communications for periodontal disease prediction which has high public health relevance. We will establish predictive models for periodontitis based on data from both sensor and patient. The new device will be useful for saliva-based self-monitoring for periodontitis and other oral or systemic diseases to improve the patient's overall health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Over fifty years of punitive criminal justice policies have created a growing population of older incarcerated individuals who are now eligible for community release but lack the social or economic capital to rebuild their lives. This study will evaluate a novel peer-run program based on network principles (i.e., social support, group cohesion, and shared instrumental resources) to help older, previously incarcerated men transition from prison to the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is the leading cause of blindness in children. There are limited therapeutic options for this severe ocular pathology. Our overall goal is to identify new and more effective therapies for ROP. In particular, we will explore and characterize the potential therapeutic effects of a short-chain fatty acid, butyrate in experimental models of ROP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The existence of latent infectious virus in brain compartments during long-term suppressive ART treatment not only elicits chronic neuroinflammation and leads to HIV-1 associated neurocognitive disorders, but also one of the major factors contributing to HIV-associated early aging in people living with HIV. The proposed multimodal approach to look at functional neuro-immune interaction at molecular level in presence of new-age combinatorial ART treatment in an animal model with functional human immune system lasting more than one year (humanized mice) will identify to what extent latent reservoirs established in the CNS disrupts molecular neuronal function during progressive aging. We will also look at how cART-mediated long-term viral suppression affects the cellular crosstalk and the brain homeostasis during progressive aging, which will provide clue to the CNS specific therapeutic targeting in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic liver disease arises as a result of chronic inflammation in the liver due to a variety of environmental insults including viral infection, alcohol consumption, and diet-induced obesity. Previous studies have demonstrated a significant recruitment of T lymphocytes to the liver during the progression of chronic liver disease, but the cause and consequence of this T cell recruitment to the liver is unknown. This project will directly address why T cells expand in the liver during the progression of NASH and if T cells promote or suppress the progression of NASH.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative PHACS 2020 is a Program Project P01 grant, consisting of the following four support Cores: Scientific Administrative Core (SAC), Data Resources Core (DRC), Health Education and Community Core (HECC), and the Epidemiological and Statistical Methods Core (ESC) to provide scientific, site and cohort infrastructure, data management and analysis, health education and community input, as well as epidemiological and statistical support to four Research Projects: 1) Surveillance Monitoring for ART Toxicities (SMARTT); 2) The Adolescent Master Protocol (AMP) Up Series (the AMP Up Series); 3) Natural History of Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) and Human Papillomavirus (HPV) in HPV Vaccinated Youth with Perinatal HIV (PHIV) (HPV); and 4; the TERBO BRAIN Study: Trajectories of Emotional Regulation and Behavior Outcomes and related Brain Regions And Intrinsic Networks (TERBO BRAIN). This multidisciplinary, interactive and synergistic P01 will address the most critical scientific questions for children, youth and young adults living with or exposed to perinatal HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telomere dysfunction due to impaired telomere maintenance leads to cellular senescence and underlies many age-related human diseases. We will develop new approaches and a unique resource to advance genomic studies of the consequences of telomere biology on the human medical phenome. These studies will have important implications in understanding the role of telomere shortening in disease and the normal aging process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphangiogenesis is crucial for fat absorption, yet little is known about the absorptive muscular-lacteal program of the regenerative intestinal villus. We find that loss of Pitx2 in mice disrupts this muscular-lacteal complex and impairs lymphatic transport of lipids, shunting them instead to the portal vein and liver, where they cause non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). While this system can be used as a model of the most common human liver disorder, our current work will define basic mechanisms underlying muscular-lacteal formation, self-renewal, and their impact on portal circulation, which are crucial to understanding and targeting fat absorption pathways in multiple gut diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) plays a prominent role in DNA adduct repair that limits the mutagenic and cytotoxic effect of alkylating agents. The goal of this research project is to apply biodegradable small-sized polymer for targeted delivery of DNA MGMT inhibitor with combination of TMZ and radiation therapy for real time monitoring of response to the treatment. Success in our study in preclinical animal tumor models should provide us with novel DNA inhibitors and methods to further develop clinical applications of such therapy options for the improved treatment of brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Congenital birth defects of the eye and retina cause structural malformations and visual impairment that can result in complete blindness. Causative genes have been identified and knowledge of their role in eye formation is providing the foundation for stem cell and regeneration-based treatments for inherited ocular defects, retinal injury, and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Animal studies have demonstrated that the regulation of food intake requires articulation among endogenous cannabinoids (ECs), fatty acid-binding proteins (FABPs), and a peroxisome proliferator- activated nuclear receptor (PPARa), but the macromolecular basis for appetite, satiety, and obesity is poorly understood. This project will probe the solution-state macromolecular structure and function of EC- FABP, EC-PPAR, and FABP-EC-PPAR complexes in vitro at near-physiological concentrations, determining affinities, metabolic fates, molecular binding interfaces, and conformational changes to test proposed mechanisms of EC metabolic signaling. Working as a team with research trainees, our work will help to understand health risks and design future therapies for heart disease, autoimmune disorders, and type-2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy is an opportunity to screen women at high-risk for cardiovascular disease so that prevention strategies can be implemented. Arterial stiffness measured by pulse wave velocity is a marker for cardiovascular disease risk. This study enrolls mother-infant pairs from healthy pregnancies and those complicated by adverse perinatal outcomes to measure maternal and infant arterial stiffness by pulse wave velocity and cardiovascular biomarkers. We will longitudinally estimate cardiovascular disease risk in healthy and medically complicated pregnant women and their infants from birth to three years postpartum.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy is an opportunity to screen women at high-risk for cardiovascular disease so that prevention strategies can be implemented. Arterial stiffness measured by pulse wave velocity is a marker for cardiovascular disease risk. This study enrolls mother-infant pairs from healthy pregnancies and those complicated by adverse perinatal outcomes to measure maternal and infant arterial stiffness by pulse wave velocity and cardiovascular biomarkers. We will longitudinally estimate cardiovascular disease risk in healthy and medically complicated pregnant women and their infants from birth to three years postpartum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shoulder pain occurs in 30-70% of patients after stroke, contributes to depression, interferes with motor recovery, and leads to decreased quality of life. However, the cause of the myofascial dysfunction has not been elucidated leading to missed opportunities for early diagnosis and variable success with treatment. This project is of significant public health importance, because it will develop quantitative imaging biomarkers of myofascial tissues and assess their ability to monitor responses and predict outcomes in post stroke shoulder pain, and aligns with the NIH HEAL Initiative to bolster research to improve treatment, prevention of opioid misuse and opioid use disorder, and enhance pain management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic studies have found hundreds of common genetic variations in the population that affect a person’s risk of a multitude of different diseases including cancer but for most of these variants, we neither know the functional reasons why they cause disease, nor the genes they interact with to drive disease development. In this proposal, we plan to use a combination of functional assays, genetic information and computational methods to work out the function of known genetic variants that influence breast, prostate and ovarian cancer risk because these cancers share common risk factors and biology and there are strong reasons to believe that some of the same genes are responsible for causing all three cancer types. We hope these approaches and the methods we use can work out the function of genetic variants and genes that cause disease, leading to clinical benefits to individuals on a population level, particularly in developing new risk prediction and prevention strategies to reduce breast, prostate and ovarian cancer incidence.

PHR: This proposal will provide new understanding of the progenitor cell function in homeostatic and diseased LGs. Our study will provide new information how lacrimal gland epithelial and progenitor cells sense inflammation and contribute to development of dry eye condition. We are confident that our new approach targeting inflammasome pathway and lacrimal gland progenitor cells will lead to development of a new therapies that improve lacrimal gland function during chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tumor microenvironment plays a pivotal role in cancer progression. Our work shows that senescent, noncancer cells contribute to breast cancer tumor progression. Thus, our work will focus on: 1) how these cells change the immune response to a growing breast tumor and metastatic tumor and 2) how eliminating these tumor promoting cells can increase susceptibility to immunotherapy to reduce breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Loss of muscle mass and function causes decreased mobility, falls, and fractures in elderly people, and though no effective therapy currently exists, chemical compounds called “indoles,” derived from the gut bacteria, limit decline in muscle function and mass and promote mobility in aging animals. Aim 1 will determine how indoles protect the muscle contractile machinery during aging; Aim 2 will determine if additional indole-regulated pathways enhance mobility during aging; Aim 3 will determine whether indoles promote the function of the mitochondria, the powerhouse of the cell whose function declines during aging whose function is dysregulated during aging. These studies will facilitate development of indoles as therapeutics for elderly people at risk for falling or losing mobility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR-T cell therapy drafts a patient's immune system (cytotoxic T cells) to target and kill tumors and its combination of pin-point specificity and broad efficacy has translated into exciting clinical data and revolutionary treatment for certain blood cancers. The major impediment to widespread use of CAR-T therapy remains its cost, which approaches $500K, a slow manufacturing process and huge regulatory hurdles for facilities that manufacture CAR-T cells. We will develop biomaterial approaches to CAR-T cell therapy, including improved methods to reprogram cells, to release cells quickly to tumors, and even to generate the CAR-T cells entirely within a patient's own body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This three-arm individual randomized controlled effectiveness trial aims to reduce childhood obesity disparities in children ages 5-8 (n=510) from low income and diverse households by increasing family meal quality (i.e., diet quality, interpersonal atmosphere) and quantity (i.e., family meal frequency). Innovative methodology (e.g., ecological momentary assessment (EMI), video feedback) will be used in partnership with primary care clinics and Community Health Workers to test three arms: (1) EMI; (2) EMI+Home Visiting (HV); and (3) EMI+HV+ Video Feedback. Findings will result in a new model for childhood obesity treatment in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cystic neoplasms (PCN) represent a common incidental finding with a prevalence of up to 24% in adults, and some PCN carry significant risk for malignancy. Current guidelines for surveillance and surgical intervention rely on symptoms and imaging features, and lead to surgical overtreatment. Development of effective early detection biomarkers in blood or cyst fluid could more accurately differentiate high risk PCN from low risk lesions, and lead to early detection of lesions with high-grade dysplasia or early stage malignancy for surgical intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) are susceptible to repeated episodes of hypoglycemia, which can result in impaired awareness of hypoglycemia (IAH). As a consequence, IAH contributes to diminished recognition of the need for external glucose. This can be a very risky situation for T1D individuals with IAH, possibly leading to coma and in some circumstances, death. The NIDDK is forming the IAH Consortium, which will conduct studies to determine if the most up-to-date management strategies using diabetes technology will restore awareness of hypoglycemia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite all our efforts, the obesity rate continues to rise in the US and worldwide. To stop this trend, we need to understand how it is that some foods cause obesity while others do not. The proposed research is relevant to this public health problem because it aims to determine how foods with different amounts of fat and carbohydrate give rise to different metabolism and ultimately different body weights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related skeletal muscle atrophy and weakness, also referred to as sarcopenia, affects millions of people, remains poorly understood, and lacks effective therapy. Toxic protein aggregates accumulate in muscles with sarcopenia, and we have uncovered ULK2 as a new protein required for degradation of protein aggregates in skeletal muscle. Because ULK2 activity is decreased with aging, by studying how ULK2 works we hope to better understand how toxic proteins accumulate in sarcopenia potentially identifying new ways to mitigate muscle atrophy and weakness in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Age-related diseases are together the leading causes of death in the United States, and drugs targeting basic mechanisms of aging have recently entered clinical trials. A hallmark of cellular aging is stochastic genetic and epigenetic drift, where cells gradually accumulate errors in their genomes and epigenomes, leading to cell-type specific aging phenotypes. This project develops computational methods and performs experiments to study how these errors propagate to the levels of transcription and RNA splicing, and how this increase in biological noise relates to known contributors to aging, particularly cellular senescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is responsible for 1 in 3 deaths among older adults, and methods of accurate, equitable, and widely available detection are needed. Digital biomarkers show promise in their ability to discern subtle neuropathological changes in early AD and address limitations of existing detection techniques. This proposal aims to formally evaluate and extend the capabilities of a novel digital biomarker, the Visuospatial Memory Eye-Tracking Test (VisMET), to detect visuospatial memory decline in early AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: New drugs developed to target Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) have a 99% failure rate; however, drug repurposing--identifying new uses for existing drugs--offers an alternative approach that can reduce the time, costs, and risks of failure associated with new drug development. The lack of systematic and readily deployable approaches to screen and validate drug repurposing signals represents a critical barrier to the success of leveraging existing public knowledge and clinical data for the advancement of AD/ADRD treatment and prevention. In direct response to the formidable challenge emphasized in PAR-20-156, we propose combining big data with advanced informatic technologies and computational capabilities to develop and share tools which systematically screen, prioritize, and validate drug repurposing candidates and their combinations for AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Transitional Care Management and Chronic Care Management and develop strategies to increase adoption of these services. This research is relevant to public health because the research findings will enable a targeted delivery of resource intensive care management services to Medicare beneficiaries who are most likely to benefit from these services. Thus, it accomplishes the National Institute on Aging's missions and initiatives to improve the health status of older adults and tame rising Medicare expenditure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: b. Project Narrative  The hallmarks of aging include stem cell exhaustion and related mitochondrial dysfunction. We have uncovered a critical role for glutamine metabolism in the muscle stem cell through both oxidative and reductive TCA pathways, which become dysfunctional with aging. Our evidence suggests restoration of the glutamine pathway(s) rejuvenates aged stem cell function and improves myogenic capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conditions affecting the bladder such as urinary tract infections (UTIs) become more common with aging and can have a severe impact on health span and quality of life, especially among postmenopausal women. Our research aims to uncover how aging predisposes the bladder to UTIs by examining proteostasis and ribosomal and endoplasmic reticulum dynamics. Completion of this work will establish a new platform for new treatments, focusing on drugs that target aging-related bladder changes.

PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells play critical roles in maintaining the lifespan of key tissue and healthspan of organisms. We believe that immune signaling in the brain causes chronic brain inflammation; therefore, modulation of this signaling would be a viable strategy to prevent neuronal loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Older individuals respond poorly to infectious agents/vaccines due, in part, to aging of the immune system (immunosenescence), a process accelerated in HIV+ individuals that is poorly understood, especially in the gastrointestinal tract, which houses more than 60% of the body’s immune cells. In this study, we aim to understand the effects of aging alone and in combination with chronic HIV infection in mucosal B-cells by studying humoral immunity to SARS-CoV2. This is of great importance as it will aid to identify possible therapies to slow or improve immunosenescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The Brain Attack Surveillance in Corpus Christi (BASIC) Project is a long-running biethnic population-based stroke study in a Mexican American and non-Hispanic white population initiated in 2000 with continuous follow- up of mortality and recurrent stroke and with post-stroke cognitive and physical assessments since 2009. Using the rich data in BASIC, the goal of this study is to measure levels of and disparities in life expectancy and cognitively and functionally healthy and unhealthy life years lived after stroke in Mexican American and non-Hispanic white persons, as well as trends in these outcomes. This data is critical to support the growing number of stroke survivors and could inform policies to improve the health of the diverse and aging US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Our gut microbiome has been linked to our susceptibility to Alzheimer's disease, but the complexity of the human microbiome makes it extremely difficult to unravel how individual bacteria influence neurodegeneration. By utilizing the relative simplicity of the Caenorhabitis elegans nervous system and microbiome, we are unraveling the molecular mechanisms of how individual bacterial species suppress neuronal degeneration. Achieving these goals will significantly advance our understanding of how degeneration is regulated by our microbiome, which is critical for developing effective strategies to protect against degenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a major health crisis, impacting millions of individuals worldwide, and its prevalence is expected to increase significantly by 2050. Current methods for diagnosing AD using positron emission tomography (PET), analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or blood biomarkers are expensive, invasive, and limited to specialized healthcare settings, highlighting the need for more accessible and affordable tests. Leveraging our extensive knowledge and experience in developing point-of-care (POC) diagnostics, we propose to develop a sensitive (LoD<10pg/mL), low-cost, easy-to-use, rapid (<30 min) smartphone-based assay to detect amyloid beta (isoforms 42 and 40), phosphorylated tau (isoforms 181, 217, and 231), and Neurofilament Light of the ATN framework in blood/plasma placed on an inexpensive (<$5 material cost), disposable, and mass-producible microfluidic-based cartridge
