IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is a process with which all organisms must contend, and mitochondria are a fundamental factor in both upstream and downstream events of cellular aging. However, many aging hypotheses related to mitochondria have remained unsolved, because our ability to control and track individual mitochondria and their morphology, genomes, functions, and interactions with other organelles as cells age has been limited. The goal of the proposed work is to implement powerful molecular and single-cell techniques in combination with in silico modeling approaches to address these limitations and gain new mechanistic insights into the role of mitochondria in cellular aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We recently showed that hypoxia reverses disease in a mouse model of mitochondrial electron transport chain complex 1 deficiency. We now propose comprehensively and mechanistically studying the ability of hypoxia to rescue a mouse model of impaired mitochondrial proteostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research holds significant public health relevance as we aim to investigate the genetic foundations of the loss of chromosome Y (LOY) and its connections to the aging process. This exploration is pivotal for deciphering LOY's role in the susceptibility to diseases linked with aging. Directly aligning with the NIA's mission, our study seeks to cultivate foundational insights that can mitigate the challenges and disabilities humans face in their later years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Precise optical scanning of 3D whole body shape is now possible with a variety of widely available commodity devices. These affordable and accessible scans may hold untapped wealth of health-related information that can be used with machine learning. In this proposal, we use this technology to develop low-cost, convenient, widely available, and accurate approaches that can augment care of older adults, and in particular for the care of individuals with sarcopenia and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project aims to understand the role of social networks in the etiology of health and health risk behaviors in the older never-married (ONM) population. We will identify intra- and interpersonal mechanisms underlying the role of social networks by collecting and analyzing the first-ever nationally representative survey data on ONM adults across two-time points. Results from this study will address a crucial unmet need for researchers and policymakers, guiding interventions to enhance the quality of life for the ONM population, while addressing the challenges they introduce to their social circles and the broader healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative One of the major obstacles to developing effective treatments for neurodegenerative diseases has been a paucity of genetic targets against which to direct therapeutic efforts. Recent human studies have revealed a robust and reproducible link between polymorphism in the Ms4a family of genes and Alzheimer’s Disease and related neurodegenerative disorders. Here, we will characterize the role of Ms4a genes in neurodegenerative pathogenesis and elucidate the mechanisms by which Ms4a genes regulate neurodegenerative processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Progranulin mutations cause frontotemporal dementia (FTD), a devastating disease for which no cure currently exists. In this project, we will test a novel therapeutic approach that uses antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) to restore normal progranulin levels in a humanized progranulin-deficient mouse model of FTD. Additionally, we will define the timing window for effective ASO treatment, as well test for potential off-target effects for lead ASOs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal aims at understanding the mechanistic underpinnings of SARS-COV-2 infection in cancer patients which lead to their worsened prognosis. We will dissect features of the innate and adaptive immune responses using unbiased holistic approaches to define the impact of the cancer host milieu on qualitative and quantitative features of the protective memory T and B cell response. Our major goal is to develop novel effective interventions to treat this severely affected population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative for Overall: The Emory SeroNet U54 program brings together a multidisciplinary team of scientists to address unmet needs relating to protective immunity against SARS CoV-2 infection. The team has a long track record of studies in viral, tumor- and autoimmunity, and will examine the nature and regulation of SARS-CoV-2 immunity in patients with autoimmunity and cancer. These studies will also provide basic insights into determinants of protective anti-viral immunity and risk of SARS-CoV-2 related immunopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Overview Our study will be centered on the ethnically/racially diverse population served by our health system in Los Angeles, given then critical need for more knowledge regarding the determinants of COVID-19 related risks in these minority subgroups. Leveraging our collective experience, resources, and infrastructure at major academic institutions from across Southern California (Cedars Sinai, UCSD, UCLA, and USC), we will advance the scientific enterprise through the three distinct yet closely integrated research Projects: Project 1 will elucidate the natural history and longitudinal trajectories that represent the diversity of SARS-CoV-2 exposure, infection, recovery, and clinical immunity patterns across the spectrum of persons at risk; Project 2 will investigate the determinants of SARS-CoV-2 response in persons with altered innate immune function, with a focus on individuals with pre-infection susceptibility traits (e.g. metabolic disease states); and, Project 3 will investigate the determinants of SARS-CoV-2 response in persons with altered adaptive immune function, with a focus on individuals with immune-altered status arising from select malignancies, autoimmune disease, and/or their directed therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Food insecurity affects 13.5 million Americans and is associated with heart disease, diabetes, and poor diet quality. This project uses a community engaged approach to collaborate with food pantries to design, implement, and evaluate digital strategies to encourage pantry clients to choose healthier foods. The goal of the proposed work is to identify acceptable and effective community interventions to improve diet quality and promote cardiovascular health equity among a vulnerable US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project 3 NARRATIVE Angiogenesis is essential for tumor growth; several anti-angiogenesis drugs including bevacizumab have been approved for clinical use but have shown only modest efficacy. This necessitates development of new anti- angiogenesis therapies. Elevated EGFL6 was reported in ovarian cancer but not in normal adult tissues; our preliminary studies showed that EGFL6 blockade in ovarian cancer models resulted in significant reduction in tumor burden without affecting wound healing. The proposed work could have significant implications for development of new anti-EGFL6 based therapies in ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Healthy Brain and Child Development (HBCD) study will encompass data collection from a cohort of 7,500 parent-child dyads across 24 independent U01 sites and three additional subcontract sites over a range of modalities including harmonized neuroimaging, neurophysiology, behavioral and cognitive assessments, and the collection of biospecimens. This administrative supplement will enable the HBCD Data Coordinating Center to fully support successful and coordinated data collection and release activities across the Consortium through the accommodation of required and unplanned costs secondary to evolving study workflows and increasing site support needs, opportunities to incorporate new data types into HBCD, changes in federal guidelines related to data sharing, and modality-specific technical requirements for analysis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project will yield the first large-scale multi-state data on pregnancy-related information needs of women with developmental disabilities that affect cognition (DD-C), and will inform future communication of a range of health messages to people with DD-C. Our proposed decision aid will help women with DD-C assess their support needs in relation to pregnancy, time their pregnancies, prepare for a healthy pregnancy if they decide they are ready for pregnancy, and communicate with medical professionals about reproductive decisions. This project directly supports NICHD's vision of “Healthy pregnancies. Healthy children. Healthy and optimal lives.”

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants born to HIV-infected mothers have altered immunity and enteric microbiota. However, our understanding of the factors influencing these changes are incomplete. The project utilizes integrative multiomic techniques and gnotobiotic mouse models to characterize the effects of the expanded gut virome of HIV-exposed infants on their bacterial microbiota and responses to vaccination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Neighborhood disadvantage (e.g., poverty and exposure to violence) is a robust indicator of youth adjustment difficulties across most domains of development, yet there are youth who thrive despite significant neighborhood adversity. This project investigates: (1) how resilience changes as youth reach important developmental milestones and freely explore their environments, (2) whether these developmental changes differ by resilience domain (psychiatric, social, emotional, academic), and (3) how warm and involved parenting as well as neighborhood protective factors might shape their development. In doing so, the proposed project can identify specific and modifiable protective factors that promote resilience to chronic neighborhood risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While early word learning is a developmental achievement that builds on a foundation of early category learning, it is unclear how children learn the visual categories that words refer to. The proposed work aims to use modern deep neural networks to understand how children’s visual experiences interact with statistical learning mechanisms to yield the category representations that support early word learning. This work will elucidate the relevant visual inputs and mechanisms for category learning and have the potential to inform interventions for children who struggle with early category learning, including late talkers, children with ASD, and children recovering from blindness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: The research program of Aliza Wingo, MD, MSc, addresses the VA priority research areas including PTSD, Alzheimer’s dementia, women veteran’s health, and genomic medicine. Particularly, Dr. Wingo studies the genetic and molecular mechanisms that underlie the conditions that disproportionally affect Veterans - PTSD, depression, Alzheimer’s dementia, and detrimental effects of maternal PTSD on offspring outcomes. Another important aspect of Dr. Wingo’s research effort is to elucidate the genetic and molecular basis of resilience, conceptualized as adaptive coping in the context of stress, adversity, or trauma. In this novel and cutting-edge CDTA application, Dr. Wingo proposes to identify proteins in the human brain that i) predispose one to PTSD or depression, and ii) contribute to resilience after adverse or traumatic life experiences. From these studies, Dr. Wingo hopes to contribute to a better understanding of the neurobiology of PTSD, depression, and Alzheimer’s dementia in order to find more effective interventions and enhance resilience among Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a pressing need to address the devastating impact of cLBP in Veteran populations. Prior research indicates that chiropractic care, increasingly integrated into the VHA system, may have a positive impact. However, chiropractic care has not been studied in the Veterans. In addition, considerable uncertainty exists regarding optimal patterns of chiropractic use. The short-term pain and functional outcomes associated with varying numbers of initial visits, and the long-term effectiveness of chiropractic care within the context of real- world delivery at VHAs, in terms of clinical impact is unknown. In addition, we know very little regarding outcomes resulting from the broader range of evidence-based chiropractic care strategies most commonly practiced in real world settings. Thus, the proposed demonstration project - an appropriately powered multisite RCT specifically designed to rigorously address both of these issues - is highly significant and has the potential to directly impact chiropractic utilization policy within the VHA and beyond, regardless of outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We invented a novel optical device which provides more than 45° of image shift to be used by patients with homonymous hemianopia or peripheral field loss as a visual aid for field expansion. In a multi-center clinical trial, we will measure collision detection performance with the proposed device, which we expect to provide greater independence and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project develops and characterizes a nanodrug that was designed and synthesized based on the compromised bacteria-regulated signaling found in human liver and colon cancers. Likely through the activation of liver and intestinal bile acid receptors, which is also reduced in human liver and colon cancers, this new drug treats Western diet-induced fatty liver, insulin resistance, and inflammation. Characterization of this first-in-class medication impacts the treatment and prevention of metabolic liver diseases, where currently no FDA-approved medications are available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in the mitotic entry control system can lead to genomic instability, a hallmark of cancer, and cell shape changes are associated with multiple stages of cancer progression including metastasis. We will use the model organism fission yeast to define of the upstream signals that govern mitotic entry and polarized growth in eukaryotes. These findings will be important to understand the cellular mechanisms that prevent untimely and inappropriate cell divisions, which contribute to human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Chronic kidney disease affects 37 million people in the U.S. and, due to limited treatment options, often progresses to kidney failure. This project aims to elucidate how disrupted iron metabolism in CKD patients impacts the key cells involved in disease progression: proximal tubular epithelial cells. The proposed studies will focus on the effects of iron on the injury and survival of these cells and will identify strategies to slow disease progression by targeting kidney iron metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Regulatory T cells (Tregs) are one of the main immune components that control autoimmune disease and are selectively disrupted in the setting of Interleukin-2 (IL-2) signaling deficiencies. Numerous studies are examining the therapeutic potential of low-dose IL-2, but these evaluations would benefit by a more complete knowledge concerning the mechanisms by which IL-2 effects mature Tregs. This study will address fundamental questions surrounding the contribution of IL-2 receptor signaling for Treg survival, differentiation, and function to aid in the therapeutic application of this cytokine and to better define potential targets related to IL-2/IL-2 receptor genetic risk for autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Antibody-based therapeutics that target the HER2 oncoprotein, such as trastuzumab, have had a transformative  impact on the survival of patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. Nevertheless, many patients develop  resistance to this form of targeted therapy, in some cases through the upregulation of a truncated form of HER2  (termed p95HER2) that lacks the epitopes recognized by these therapeutic antibodies. This project will elucidate  the impact of p95HER2 on the tumor immune microenvironment and evaluate potential new strategies for  treating p95HER2-positive breast cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The deregulation of autophagy and heightened inflammation has been implicated in dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This proposal will use a novel mouse model and human iPSC-derived RPE cells from controls and AMD risk allele containing donors to decipher a yet unknown role of the crosstalk between the autophagy and inflammatory processes in the pathogenesis of dry AMD. We envisage that the proposed studies will help to develop strategies, potentially leading to novel therapies for this disease, which has no treatment available at the moment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysanapsis, the mismatch between airway tree and lung size, is a common structural variation in the lung that is a better predictor of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease than smoking and all previously described risk factors. In this R01 study, our objective is to examine the relationship between early-life exposures and both structural (lung MRI-assessed) and functional (spirometry-assessed) measures of dysanapsis throughout childhood and adolescence. We will leverage 8 longitudinal birth cohorts of diverse children to identify modifiable risk factors for dysanapsis and help reduce risk of COPD in future generations at risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An estimated 7 million stroke survivors are living in the United States. More than two-thirds of these have residual paralysis of the upper limb, and of them, ~37%-65% have moderate-to-severe paralysis. Few treatment options are appropriate or effective for these patients. Here, we will test whether combining a unique rehabilitation therapy of brain and nerve stimulation improves hand movement after moderate-to-severe stroke.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthening task specific activation of paretic hand muscles after moderateto- severe chronic stroke

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Driving lymphoid potential in multipotent hematopoietic progenitors by linker histones Narrative This proposal aims to define a molecular pathway that regulates the lineage output of multipotent HSPCs by linker histones. The genomic targets of linker histones in HSPCs will be determined. We will also test whether protease inhibitors that can increase linker histone proteins can boost hematopoietic differentiation toward the lymphoid lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease accounts for 1 in every 3 deaths in the US, typically as a result of pathological cardiac remodeling and subsequent heart failure, for which there is no cure. As the percentage of obese individuals continues to grow at an alarming rate, coming to the forefront in cardiovascular medicine is that the pathophysiology of the majority of heart failure patients involves a multi-organ syndrome in which cardiac, inflammatory, metabolic and other systems result in the diagnosis of what has been recently coined heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The studies proposed here aim to decipher the molecular mechanisms contributing to HFpEF, with the anticipation that understanding these mechanisms will help us to develop novel and selective therapeutic avenues for intervention and, thus, reduce mortality from this form of cardiovascular disease and associated obesity-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: Coronary microvascular dysfunction is associated with coronary artery diseases, diabetic cardiomyopathy, and HFpEF (heart failure with preserved ejection fraction). The current proposal is to study the underlying mechanism of a switch of mediator in endothelial-dependent vasodilation from NO to H2O2 in a pre-clinical diabetic model characterized by coronary microvascular dysfunction and how miR-21 regulates the switch and its consequence in myocardial blood flow in diabetic cardiomyopathy. We will establish novel therapeutic strategies to restore coronary microvascular function and stop the progress of diabetic cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is the deadliest gynecologic malignancy in the U.S. and innovative approaches for achieving optimal outcomes are desperately needed. We propose to establish a multi-institutional cohort of racially and ethnically diverse women with the most common and one of the deadliest histotypes of ovarian cancer, high- grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC), with standard of care (SOC) computed tomography (CT) images prior to treatment and well-annotated clinical and outcomes data to identify and validate image-based features predictive of survival. This work will provide readily calculable, non-invasive biomarkers from SOC CT images for clinically translational information to aid in patient stratification efforts that will ultimately improve outcomes among women with HGSOC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Recognizing that chronic diseases, including Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and Related Dementia (AD/ADRD), do not exist solely as isolated entities, the use of large longitudinal datasets such as electronic health records (EHRs) becomes a key novel asset with potential to advance understanding and management of dynamic personalized risk in the layered complexity involving variations through risk factors, and concomitant diseases. Thus, we propose to federate a unique multiethnic 3-city EHR consortium in NY, Miami and Chicago, encompassing 9 million patients records (59,000 of them with AD/ADRD) embedded in census-track level social determinants of health, and to use machine learning and novel dynamic predictive and causal inference methods to identify accelerators or decelerators of AD/ADRD. This work will inform strategies to tailor risk prediction, inform complex clinical management and build a multiethnic harmonized dynamic platform ready for real-world evaluation of future treatments of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE β-cells adapt their insulin secretory response to compensate for increased insulin demand in obesity; however long-term overnutrition can also become maladaptive and lead to β-cell failure and diabetes. How β-cells read nutrient signals and translate these signals into adaptive and maladaptive responses is poorly understood. Here, we will determine how regulation of the β-cell epigenome by the nutrient-sensitive histone demethylase LSD1 mediates adaptive and maladaptive processes in β-cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this MIRA project is to develop data-driven and AI empowered systems biology approaches to accurate assess biological processes by using omics data, including a natural language processing-based model construction, a new AI framework to approximate systems biology models, and related computational principles. The proposed framework will systematically characterize the biological processes, such as metabolic and signaling pathways, as well as their heterogeneities and crosstalk in disease tissue microenvironment, and identify key influencing factors in complex disease by analyzing omics data. Given the pervasive role of metabolism and signaling pathways in essentially every aspect of the disease pathology, the proposed infrastructure with accurate characterization of functional variations could have far-reaching impact in our knowledge on the basis of disease biology, clinical early diagnosis and prevention, and disease management.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This two-phase “health equity acceleration” U01 application is submitted to participate in the FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award for “Racial & Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) (U01)” focused on advancing “minority health and health equity focused research, outreach, and communications as well as support training and mentoring of diverse HBCU advanced students, fellows, and researchers.” Two pilot projects/programs submitted in this application will be developed under Phase 1, and subsequently implemented under Phase 2: a) A Pilot curriculum on “Regulatory Issues and Health Equity” and potential FDA OMHHE rotations for advanced students and faculty in HBCUs in Pharmacy (XULA College of Pharmacy) and Nursing (Helene Fuld School of Nursing CSU); and b) A Pilot research project which will move the discussion beyond barrier identification to develop strategies to address barriers to clinical trial diversity, in order to increase trustworthiness, enhance transparency in sponsors and researchers, and bolster willingness to participate for African Americans, thereby strengthening equity in participation of underrepresented minority racial and ethnic groups in clinical trials.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Racial and Ethnic Minority Acceleration for Health Equity Consortium U01

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks the establishment of the Puerto Rico Racial & Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (PR-REACH) to support the advancement of Hispanic Puerto Ricans health equity, this is a first step in a research agenda to collaborate with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Office of Minority Health and Health Equity (OMHHE) across REACH research projects and activities by first building an administrative research and communication infrastructure; leadership team, three EQUITY research cores (Clinical Trials, Voices and Data), a training and mentoring core, and an advisory team. A pilot study under this consortium will be conducted to advance the understanding of substance use disorder patients’ journey as perspectives, preferences and unmet needs regarding substance use disorder (SUD) treatment with FDA approved medications in PR to be able to improve its outcomes and launch PR-REACH in PR. The PR-REACH will initiate with Hispanics living in Puerto Rico as a model than can inform and guide subsequent extrapolation to Hispanics in the US in collaboration with the FDA.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The advent of remote technologies such as video conferencing and secure web-portals have revolutionized approaches to health data collection and access to healthcare, where these technologies can be deployed in fully remote and hybrid approaches for clinical trials which could help promoting more participation among under-represented groups as well as by bridging geographic distance and reducing participant burden (e.g., less travel time, more flexibility and confidentiality). However, these approaches have yet to be optimized for all possible beneficiaries of technological advances in clinical trials and healthcare, especially targeting under- represented populations that are disproportionately experiencing social and geographic isolation. To address these concerns, the current proposal seeks to leverage the team’s existing community connections in states across 4 different regions of the U.S. among the Asian American and Pacific Islander (including Native Hawaiian), American Indian, Hispanic/Latino, and sexual and gender minority populations to: (1) (a) co-create and maintain 4 virtual and hybrid advisory groups to address health issues and (b) develop materials for the conduct of remote advisory groups; (2) co-develop and administer a national needs assessment survey for the referenced 4 groups (N = 800) addressing the use of home self-testing technology (up to 3 types) and remote data collection for healthcare research and healthcare provision; and (3) pilot community driven approaches to introducing home self-testing technology and remote data collection to potential participants from these groups to assess feasibility and acceptability.
PI_NAMEs: FLORES MILLENDER, EUGENIA  (contact);WONG, FRANK Y.;XAVIER HALL, CASEY DANIEL

PROJECT_TITLE: Elevating Community Voices by Developing a User-centered Approach to Enable Self-testing and Remote Data Collection among Under-represented Populations (Project Elevate)

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Three sentences   With a collaborative approach grounded in Indigenous core cultural values, the Indigenous Innovators Collaborative (IIC) team will engage in community-based participatory research study to address the FDA priorities as outlined in FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award: Racial and Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) funding opportunity. The IIC seeks to engage American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) communities, stakeholders, researchers in an exploration of clinical trials and promote cultural knowledge in understanding clinical trials in Indian Country. One of the fundamental goals of this study is to aid in identifying perceptions of clinical trials and gene therapy within the Native American population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Improving Restoration of Middle-Ear Function Following Blast-Related Injuries Because of the environments in which military personnel operate, they are significantly more likely to suffer service-related hearing losses. Restoration of hearing following conductive hearing loss due to excessive blast- related noises has had limited success, because the hearing field currently has only a rudimentary understanding of how the structures of the middle ear transmit sound under pathological conditions. The studies in the current proposal will significantly advance our knowledge of how middle-ear structures work to accurately transmit sound. By measuring sound-pressure levels and movements of middle-ear structures in normal and damaged ears, we can more precisely diagnose the specific causes of a blast-induced hearing loss, and design and implement more effective surgical methods and replacement prosthetics to optimally restore hearing. The knowledge gained from the proposed research will be of value not only in habilitating military personnel and Veterans, but also for other patients suffering from conductive hearing losses.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 30,000 veterans are hospitalized for stroke each year, and in the critical first months of recovery, at least half are disabled by abnormal 3-D spatial function (spatial neglect). Their self-care, mobility, and ability to return home are severely limited. Worse, many of these veterans are never diagnosed, counseled about the problem, or prescribed spatial rehabilitation. Here, we attempt to speed up spatial neglect diagnosis, using the brain imaging that is always part of the first hours of stroke care. We will compare 4 methods to identify the special brain imaging features present in people with spatial neglect who respond to early rehabilitation, and who recover best at 3 and 6 months after stroke. Once we complete this study, the next step will be to confirm our findings in a larger project, to ensure clinical brain imaging can be used for treatment assignment in veterans across gender, race, and other characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fatty liver disease and chronic kidney disease, affecting tens of millions of people in the US alone, exhibit pathological dysregulation of lipid metabolism, which is heavily dependent on the pivotal cofactor coenzyme A (CoA). CoA is synthesized from the essential nutrient vitamin B5 and is absolutely required for lipid synthesis, fatty acid oxidation, and the TCA cycle among other critical pathways, but little attention has been paid to how CoA supplies are actively coordinated with metabolic and biosynthetic demands, including in kidney and liver. Completion of our aims in both mammalian and fly models will reveal new regulatory mechanisms (metabolite signals and signaling pathways) for CoA synthesis, advance our mechanistic understanding of the in vivo roles of CoA synthesis enzymes, establish novel tools and models, and provide foundational knowledge for potentially manipulating CoA synthesis as a new therapeutic strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The marmoset is an increasingly attractive non-human primate (NHP) model for understanding neurophysiology and there is a major interest in the field for using it to study neurodegenerative diseases, particularly to model the social and cognitive deficits that accompany them, which current animal models are unable to do. At present, no NHP models exist with trinucleotide repeat mutations at the endogenous allele as occurs in Huntington’s disease, in part because of limitations in the ability of the CRISPR/Cas9 system to introduce long stretches of DNA, as well as limitations in marmoset reproductive technologies. Therefore, we propose to establish a new strategy that utilizes the expanded developmental potential of ground-state pluripotent cells to generate animals that carry the precise human mutation through assistant reproductive technologies, which we believe will pave the road for transgenic marmoset models as superior preclinical models to transgenic mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposed research is to identify novel pathways to prevent or slow Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias (ADRD) by investigating the primary drivers of cognitive resilience. We aim to generate a detailed biological framework for understanding how an individual's underlying genetic architecture and environmental factors combine to produce cognitive resilience in older adults. These results will be critical for designing future public health strategies and clinical interventions to reduce the burden of ADRD by fostering cognitive resilience in aging populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. Deaf community – a group of more than 500,000 Americans who communicate using American Sign Language (ASL) – experiences nearly triple the rate of lifetime problem drinking and twice the rate of trauma exposure compared to the general population. Although there are several treatments for alcohol use disorder (AUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in hearing populations, none have been developed for or tested with Deaf clients. To address these barriers, our team developed Signs of Safety, a Deaf-accessible therapy toolkit for treating AUD and PTSD. We propose a nationwide, virtual clinical trial to compare (1) Signs of Safety with (2) treatment as usual and (3) a no treatment control, to collect data on clinical outcomes, and to explore potential mediators and moderators of outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Splicing of gene transcripts is an essential process in human cells and frequently dysregulated in disease. Despite progress, the molecular-level mechanisms of splice site identification are incompletely understood. We seek to understand how the splicing machinery identifies gene transcripts for processing into legible RNA messages, thereby providing context for personalized medicines to treat patients with dysfunctional splicing.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how cells in the embryo interpret complex signals to create organs is one of the most challenging and important questions in biology. We propose to develop in vitro models of organ development by combining human stem cells, advanced tissue engineering, and genomic editing techniques that will allow us to study de- tailed molecular mechanisms of organ formation in the human gut, from the lungs to the large intestine. The proposed work will significantly advance the current paradigms in stem cell biology and will innovate technol- ogies of recreating precise human organ tissues in a lab, and eventually enable high-throughput drug screening, and physiological modeling of gut homeostasis, chronic inflammation, and infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project optimizes a new, safe imaging technology using a combination of light and sound in large animal eye models of wet macular degeneration. Imaging characteristics predicting lack of response to treatment are determined, and new nanoparticles for enhancement of imaging which are able to be safely excreted in the urine are evaluated. The long term goal of this project is to develop a multimodal molecular imaging using gold nanoparticles to image biomarkers predicting response to treatment to develop novel therapies of eye diseases.

PHR: RUTGERS CANCER INSTITUTE OF NEW JERSEY PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The catchment area of Rutgers Cancer Institute of New Jersey (CINJ) is the state of New Jersey (NJ), with a diverse population of over 9.2 million. CINJ is the State of New Jersey's only National Cancer Institute (NCI)- designated Comprehensive Cancer Center. The mission of CINJ is to reduce the burden of cancer by advancing cancer research, prevention, screening and education for the most densely-populated and one of the most ethnically and socioeconomically diverse states in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the delivery problem to treat or possibly prevent hearing loss. The proposal describes an ex vivo platform for testing transport and uptake of therapeutics into the inner ear and explores the potential of nanovesicles specially exosomes to enhance intratympanic transport of therapeutics that are currently considered for clinical trials or are in the clinical trial (neurotrophins for regeneration of neurons and AAVs (gene therapy) and small molecules (Chir and VPA) for regeneration of hair cells) in vitro and in vivo. Since the success of this research would open a new delivery horizon to advance regeneration and pharmacotherapeutics to treat and prevent hearing loss, the work is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There remains a need to adopt cross-functional strategies to reduce the high costs and long lead times for developing novel models for functional precision medicine. As a solution, Xilis is leveraging its multi-disciplinary team to advance the commercial development of our benchtop microfluidic instrument that can rapidly generate and scale micro-organospheres (MOS) – high-fidelity, ex vivo patient avatars, which can predict patient response to treatments. Successful completion of this project will lead to a commercial-grade, automated instrument that can be readily plugged into the clinical workflow to expedite various downstream applications including diagnostic assay and drug development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Vestibular dysfunction is a significant public health problem with evidence of postural instability has been reported in 35% of older adults, yet the effects of noise, on central vestibular pathways and resulting behavioral dysfunction are understudied. The proposed studies will expand our knowledge of afferent irregular fiber contributions to activation of vestibular nuclei, by assessing neuronal activity, indicators of synaptic transmission, and behavioral performance following bilateral noise-induced hypofunction. In the future, these results will contribute to the development of targets and a temporal window for pharmacotherapeutic intervention to direct vestibular rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal aims to understand how secretory and membrane proteins are properly synthesized and folded in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The ER-resident sensor molecules monitor and adjust the protein folding capacity of the ER according to demand. We previously discovered that one of the sensor molecules, IRE1, forms a direct complex with the protein translocation machinery in the ER. In this proposal, we will mechanistically understand how both IRE1 and protein translocation machinery work together to maintain ER homeostasis, which is fundamentally important for producing functional molecules, including antibodies, hormones, and transport proteins.

PROJECT_TITLE: The interplay between the UPR and protein biogenesis at the ER

PHR: Project Narrative Duke University, a major research university, and North Carolina Central University, a historic black university, both in Durham, NC partner for this career development program in women’s health research. Selected junior faculty members and one postdoctoral trainee from these two institutions receive formal mentoring and training to conduct interdisciplinary research relevant to women’s health across the lifespan emphasizing health disparities and the effects that sex and gender have on health. These well- trained scientists will be the future champions for improving women’s health nationwide and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: New Methods and Chemical Tools Against Multi Drug-resistant Bacterial Infections Project Narrative/Relevance Multi-drug resistance bacterial infections are a global health crisis that urgently needs new antibacterials with novel mechanisms of action. This proposal outlines our approach to identifying new and effective antibacterials via an innovative targeted protein degradation strategy and inhibiting novel bacterial targets using the 19F NMR ligand screening platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in proteins inducing widespread transcriptomic or genomic changes are widely implicated in human disease. However, determining which mutations are pathogenic vs. benign remains a significant challenge in clinical applications of next-generation sequencing analysis. This project develops complementary pooled genome editing and computational approaches to interpret the impact of individual mutations to regulatory and DNA repair genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Over the last twenty years from the early days of linkage and candidate gene studies to the ongoing whole- genome sequencing efforts, the family-based association testing (FBAT) approach and its software implementation have become a popular and essential tool for the genetic association analysis of family data. The model-free character of the approach, its robustness against any form of genetic confounding, and the user- friendly implementation have fostered the research of a large user community and contributed to several thousand research papers. In this application, to better address the current and future data analysis challenges of the community, we propose to modernize the FBAT program by incorporating new methodological features and improving the technical capabilities of the implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this administrative supplement to our UC Davis BIRCWH program (PI, Dr. Nancy Lane), we propose to build on the experience and achievements of our previous 21 years of the program to advance, promote, and achieve interdisciplinary training and mentoring of team-based science for the next generation of researchers in women's health and sex differences. We are requesting to continue supporting our BIRCWCH Scholar who is from an underrepresented minority group and disadvantaged background to our program for two years. We believe that our BIRCWH faculty, mentors, and this additional Scholar will work to improve the health of women and to improve our knowledge and understanding of the mechanisms and manifestations of sex differences in health and disease as well as of the unique afflictions women face with the ultimate goal of more effective prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Aligning with the 2019-23 Trans-NIH Plan for Women’s Health Research, the long-term objective of the UIC BIRCWH is to promote training and careers to develop a well-trained, diverse, and robust workforce to advance science for the health of women. Through evidence-based mentoring practices, innovative training strategies, and strong internal and external multidisciplinary collaborations, the UIC BIRCWH improves recruitment, retention, and advancement of women and URMs as scientists and academic leaders in interdisciplinary women’s health and sex/gender differences research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Medical Science Training Program (MSTP) at the Medical College of Wisconsin (MCW) provides integrated basic science and medical training as the educational foundation for future academic physician scientists. The mission of MCW-MSTP is to prepare students for careers as physician-scientists, which allows students to conduct hypothesis-driven research and to practice evidence-based medicine as an MD-PhD. MCW-MSTP welcomes all applicants, including students of diversity, students with disabilities, and students from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Our understanding of Treponema pallidum, and by extension syphilis, has been hindered by the lack of an in vitro culture system for over a century. The proposed research will test the hypothesis that T. pallidum naturally secretes muropeptides that drive syphilis pathogenesis. This work will therefore describe the biochemical features of released T. pallidum PG, elucidate its role in T. pallidum pathogenesis, and create a custom CRISPR platform that can be used for future investigation of T. pallidum biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of the proposed Direct to Phase II SBIR project is to commercialize Continuous Countercurrent Tangential Chromatography (CCTC) for recombinant AAV purification. This novel platform will enable column-free, continuous, and single-use purification of rAAVs. Successful commercialization of the CCTC system in this field will lead to at least a 50% reduction in downstream production costs, increased recoveries (by 40%) and improved product quality for these life saving therapies that provide effective treatments and cures for such conditions as cancer, hemophilia and many others.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project narrative: Antimicrobial resistance in bacteria has become a significant concern in human health. The lack of antimicrobial stewardship and increased use of antimicrobial drugs in animal feeds has led to the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacterial pathogens from companion and food-producing animals. The availability of benchtop DNA sequencing platforms provides an accurate whole- genome sequence (WGS) for a broad range of bacteria in less than a day. Thus, identifying genetic determinants of antimicrobial resistance and typing of clinically critical bacterial pathogens help accurately define the transmission of drug-resistant and multi-drug-resistant organisms. The work performed under this project will allow a continuing collaboration with Center for Veterinary Medicine’s Vet-LIRN into investigating of human and animal food safety using Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Vet-LIRN Network Capacity-Building Project: Bacterial Whole Genome Sequencing

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: FDA CVM Vet-LIRN PROGRAM (U18) GRANT PROPOSAL  FOR FOA # PAR-22-063 from the OHIO DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL DISEASE DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY PROJECT NARRATIVE The FDA Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN) enables analyses of animal diagnostic samples and animal food/drug products. Through Vet-LIRN, the FDA leverages the expertise of a national network of veterinary diagnostic laboratories to provide additional capability and capacity to strengthen the overall national food safety system. The Ohio Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory (ADDL) will offer its expertise and services to support testing and surveillance projects under direction from Vet-LIRN, provide surge capacities for testing using standardized Vet-LIRN methods, and assist Vet-LIRN with emergency response testing.

PROJECT_TITLE: FDA Vet-LIRN Infrastructure Support for Ohio ADDL

PHR: Project Narrative: Through a collaboration with the FDA’s Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN), the Louisiana Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory will work toward the common mission of promoting human and animal health by expanding our diagnostic capabilities and capacity for routine and emergency response. The continued support of laboratories in this network is crucial for strengthening national food safety by providing rapid detection and response in a large-scale outbreak or emergency event.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Testing for antimicrobial resistance in sick animals is needed to support the mission of FDA to protect public health. In 2017, FDA Vet-LIRN launched a surveillance initiative including whole genome sequencing as a key component for mitigating the lack of standardization in antibiotic susceptibility testing in their network. Sequencing methods are now standardized across six laboratories in the network, including at Cornell, and we are requesting support for these activities for the next five years.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Genomic surveillance for antimicrobial resistance in animals

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: FDA CVM Vet-LIRN PROGRAM PROPOSAL  FOR FOA PAR-23-202 “FDA Vet-LIRN Network Capacity-Building Project and Equipment Grants” NARRATIVE This Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN) capacity building project strengthens the capacity, collaboration, and integration of food-safety laboratories and networks, thereby facilitating an effective and coordinated response to future human and animal food safety issues. The Vet-LIRN at the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Animal Diseases Diagnostic Laboratory at the Ohio Department of Agriculture (Ohio ADDL) will collaborate to perform whole genome sequencing (WGS) of foodborne pathogen isolates. This project will support the identification and adoption of emerging technologies and the harmonization of analytical methods used by equipment platforms for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) studies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: FDA Vet-LIRN Cooperative Agreement with Ohio ADDL to support projects and work associated with One Health, animal food issues, antimicrobial resistance, and surge capacity testing.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative This goal of this application is to enhance the veterinary diagnostic capacity and capabilities of Animal Disease Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (ADRDL), South Dakota in support of improving the national food safety system. This project will allow ADRDL to participate in Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN). Through this program, ADRDL will serve as a regional sequencing lab and also will perform diagnostic testing as required by Vet-LIRN.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthening national food safety system by improving veterinary diagnostics

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) monitoring is a critical function for veterinary diagnostic laboratories to aid in identification of new or emerging resistance, to identify potential resistance reservoirs, and assess efficacy of interventions to reduce resistance development. Not only do resistant bacterial infections impact animal health and welfare, but they also have significant potential for causing negative human health consequences through transmission of resistant bacteria or resistance genes through food or animal contact. Whole genome sequence AMR data form important veterinary bacterial pathogens and improvements in standardized data quality assurance/quality control for bacterial resistance detection increases the ability of FDA Center for Veterinary Medicine to accurately detect resistance and provide more accurate monitoring of antimicrobial resistance in veterinary species.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring of Bacterial Pathogens of Veterinary Concern

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Living kidney donation is an effective treatment for selected patients with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), but it is not without risks, and long-term health risks vary by race, sex, and age, and there is a lack of evidence-based guidelines for preserving renal function in living kidney donors (LKDs). This research project aims to inform recruitment methods and engage the community in a study which will identify predonation and postdonation risk factors, including genetic factors, associated with ESKD in LKDs. The study will have a significant impact on the care and well-being of LKDs, benefiting the large number of individuals who have already donated a kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Racial disparities for Black Americans compared to White Americans have persisted in multiple aspects of chronic kidney disease (CKD), from incidence and prevalence to care and outcomes. This project will trace back to the period preceding CKD to identify root causes of these disparities. Understanding the sources of these disparities will serve to minimize them and improve the care and health outcomes of Black Americans in the U.S.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The rate of suicide among US military Veterans is approximately 50% higher than among non-Veterans. Suicide is a complex phenomenon that is highly associated with social determinants of health (SDH) including housing instability, justice involvement, and unemployment. Using existing Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) administrative data, and environmental scan of VA support programs, and qualitative interviews with VA support program staff and Veterans, this study will determine whether and how services to address SDH mitigate Veterans’ risk of suicide. Results will lay the groundwork to develop implementation trials to bolster VA and community social support services as non-medical components of suicide prevention for Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Significance: The proposed project could rapidly accelerate a promising new treatment for chronic complex TBI that is supported by strong preliminary data and builds upon compelling research findings. If allopregnanolone (ALLO) is efficacious and well-tolerated in this population, a larger Phase 2 or Phase 3 randomized controlled trial (RCT) would be the next logical step for this molecule - which has the potential to address an urgent unmet clinical need for Veterans with chronic complex TBI and commonly co-occurring conditions such as depression and pain symptoms, and to positively impact functional outcome and quality of life in this population. A longer-acting formulation of ALLO is also a possibility and under development in our laboratory. In the interim, the proposed pilot RCT using intravenous ALLO would provide critical pharmacokinetic data in this chronic complex TBI cohort, in addition to potential initial clinical signals for therapeutic efficacy and biomarker candidate identification to inform future efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients diagnosed with Scleroderma (SSc), a disease resulting in the progressive scarring of the skin and lungs, have a significantly increased risk of lung cancer, or Cancerous Scleroderma (CSc). The main cell type that is responsible for this severe scarring promotes the development of lung cancer in SSc patients, hence this research aims to uncover ways to target these pathogenic cells to resolve CSc. There is no currently established treatment to reverse scarring in any organ, therefore the impact of the novel insights gained from this research will be tremendous.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM) is a highly aggressive form of brain cancer with a fatality rate close to 100% despite aggressive therapies, primarily because the invasive nature and inaccessibility of the tumors makes recurrence after treatment very common and treatment efficacy hard to assess. We have developed a system that can provide serial direct tissue biopsy of the tumor, allowing for collection of data about the tumor genetic profile and treatment efficacy that will allow clinicians to make more informed decisions about treatment course and accelerate entrance into suitable clinical trials. This information will empower clinicians by giving them access to an unprecedented level of information about tumor response to treatment in real time, allowing them to enhance the effectiveness of current treatments, increase the efficiency of clinical trials, and finally improve GBM outcomes that have not changed in decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL There were an estimated 1.7 million new cases of cancer in the United States in 2018, and an estimated 609,000 deaths from the disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to define the function and biological significance of a class of peptides (RaS-RiPPs) produced by oral Streptococci, and to examine their impact on the human oral microbiota. Understanding how these compounds modulate the oral microbiome and the activity of their own host species represents an important gap in knowledge concerning one of the major groups of oral microorganisms. In turn, these data will provide a foundation for examining their impact on the host and oral niche.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transposable elements are prevalent selfish DNA sequences present in many organisms, and they constitute about 45% of the human genome. Their activity and abundance are related to their ability to cause inherited diseases and cancers, including breast cancer, colon cancer, and leukemia. The proposed research will identify factors that influence the abundance of transposable elements and determine their consequences on host function and fitness, with strong implications for human health and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will collect data on early childhood risk factors for eating disorders in female children ages 6-12. The proposed research has significant public health relevance, as it will enhance our understanding of how eating disorders develop and for whom, leading to early detection and prevention efforts. The proposed research is relevant to NIMH’s strategic aim 3.1. A to strive for prevention based on an understanding of risk, as it will lead to tools that can better identify early risk factors, as well as prevention efforts directly targeting mechanisms predictive of the onset of early eating disorders and related pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an unmet clinical need to adjust the number and location of the acquired echocardiographic planes, which is crucial for assessment of heart valves, strain imaging and cardiac fluid dynamics enabled by multiplanar echocardiographic particle image velocimetry (MP-Echo-PIV). This project aims to devise a novel generation of 4D transthoracic echocardiography (4D TTE) systems using matrix arrays with a beamformer to enable operator- controlled multiplanar acquisition at high volume-rates. These latest systems will accommodate accurate assessment of blood flow patterns in the heart through high-speed multiplanar acquisitions.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because improving the longevity of total knee arthroplasty would help the over 750,000 patients undergoing knee replacement annually by ultimately helping to delay or avoid revision surgeries. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative To truly understand the value of MRI in guiding decisions about heart-failure with preserved ejection fraction, we will develop and test MRI methods similar to echocardiography in measuring elevated pressures in the heart. One method evaluates flow in leaky heart-valves (called regurgitation), using a constantly moving slice that zeros in on the heart-valve region. We develop a feasible method for evaluating the pressure in the heart, at rest and with exercises such as hand-grip, and determine their accuracy in patients, by comparing to the best available values (pressures obtained by catheterization).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preserving the genetic privacy of participants in research studies is critical for maintaining the trust of participants thus increasing study participation, as well as for enabling data sharing, thus facilitating important biomedical discoveries. The ability to accomplish this goal requires the development of efficient privacy-preserving tools. In order to keep up with the changing legal landscape and undisruptive access to analysis and protect patients' and research participants' privacy, our long term goal is to create a privacy-enhancing, cloud-ready, user-friendly, evolving, and modular omics tool ecosystem, which can be adapted to new data modalities and analysis needs as they arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  This supplement project seeks to evaluate a new series of compounds that have been developed to correct germline mutations in the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor, which predispose individuals to multiple forms of cancer. Using the CP4.29 compound and a series of related analogs, we will create and employ cell models expressing common germline mutations in VHL, and assess the ability of the compounds to repair the pro-oncogenic effect of the mutations. If successful, the resulting data will inform the further development of these compounds to intercept cancers in patients with germline VHL mutations.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because altered glycosylation is a signature of many diseases, including cancer, infection, and neurodegenerative disorders, there is a need for reagents with high affinity and specificity for detecting glycans. We will optimize the specificity of Fbs1 for glycopeptides and glycoproteins that contain asparagine- linked (N-linked) carbohydrate chains using computationally-guided directed evolution. The resulting reagent will have broad utility in glycoscience research, including glycomics and glycoproteomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic nonbacterial osteomyelitis (CNO) is a severe autoinflammatory bone disease that causes debilitating complications and poor quality of life. Assessments of disease activity, comparison of effectiveness of various durations of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, selection of second-line treatments have been challenging due to rarity of CNO. Our proposed study will leverage our existing CHronic nonbacterial Osteomyelitis International Registry (CHOIR), validated clinical disease assessment score (CDAS) and secondary imaging outcome to address these knowledge gaps and provide evidence for improved clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Teleophthalmology using retinal cameras in primary care clinics has been shown to improve diabetic eye screening rates and visual outcomes, but remains greatly underutilized in the U.S. This multi-center randomized controlled trial proposes to test the effectiveness and generalizability of a promising implementation program (I- SITE: Implementation to Sustain Impact in Teleophthalmology) for sustaining increased diabetic eye screening rates using teleophthalmology in rural health systems. This research seeks to identify methods for successful integration of telemedicine technology into rural primary care workflows to prevent blindness from diabetes, the leading cause of blindness among working-age U.S. adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is a joint replacement of non-anatomic design that relieves pain and restores arm elevation, but many patients lose arm rotational range of motion or experience functional deficits. Patient- specific humeral anatomy is not currently considered during the procedure but offers opportunities to optimize shoulder function by improving muscle efficacy through its relationship to humeral implant placement. This research challenges the standard of care in reverse shoulder arthroplasty, thereby influencing pre-operative planning, implant designs, the procedure, and rehabilitation, with the objective to restore shoulder function and set realistic and reliable expectations for the surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Hair follicle stem cells (HFSCs) are multipotent epithelial stem cells that fuel the production of hair follicles throughout the life of an organism. We have recently identified that the key chromatin regulator, the Polycomb complex, not only plays a critical role in HFSCs but also exerts its function via a novel mechanism of gene regulation. By dissecting the molecular mechanisms of Polycomb-mediated regulation of HFSCs, we aim to gain insight into the regulation of HFSC during normal homeostasis as well as uncover processes that go awry in human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The introduction of clinical exome sequencing and whole genome sequencing has transformed our ability to diagnose patients with suspected genetic disease. However, up to 70% of patients with suspected genetic disease remain undiagnosed likely because their disease-causing variant(s) has yet to be discovered or the clinical significance of variants identified in genomic studies remains unclear. The BCM Center for Precision Medicine Modeling will support local, national, and international programs and individual researchers in the development of precision animal models that end the diagnostic odyssey of patients with undiagnosed, rare, and Mendelian diseases and serve as resources for pre-clinical studies investigating personalized medicine approaches to their care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall The Harvard University CFAR (HU CFAR) provides the infrastructure to coordinate, support and add value to Harvard investigators’ cutting-edge multidisciplinary HIV research programs and to forge new collaborations and synergies. The HU CFAR pursues innovative initiatives to address critical HIV-related research priorities and train the next generation of HIV researchers. By leveraging the exceptional strengths of Harvard and its institutional support, the HU CFAR promises to continue to provide major leadership in the global effort to prevent and treat HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although there are significant sex differences in the expression and onset of major medical and psychiatric disorders, clinical decisions based on research are still based primarily on data from men and may often be inappropriate for women. Thus, there remains a strong need for the Harvard BIRCWH program to educate, train, and develop junior investigators who will commit their careers to studying the impact of sex and gender on clinical disorders. Our Harvard BIRCWH program will provide the basis for the development of sex- dependent treatment approaches and public awareness of the importance of these sex-dependent health issues for families and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The study of patients with rare diseases may provide insights that benefit patients with common diseases. To complement our iPSC-based model, we generated a large animal model of the rare human disease Progressive Pseudorheumatoid Arthropathy of Childhood (PPAC) in order to understand its pathobiology. Knowledge gained from our studies will be relevant and applicable to patients with PPAC and could benefit patients with common degenerative joint diseases, such as osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is an aggressive disease with limited treatment options. We find that Gα13, a signaling mediator of G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) which are major target of approved drugs, regulates mTORC1- mediated tumor metabolism and inflammation. In this proposal we will determine whether Gα13 status determine the susceptibility to perturbations of metabolism and inflammatory mediators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is aimed at understanding why some patients develop high blood pressure in the lungs (pulmonary arterial hypertension, PAH). PAH is a serious and progressive disease with no cure and with 5-year mortality as great as 50%. In particular, we are trying to understand how the loss of capillaries and narrowing of arteries vessels happen and why they cause PAH development, and develop a new effective therapeutic strategy for the treatment of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tough fibrous interfaces between tissues are a common location of injury and source of pathology, pain and disability. Surgical repairs of interfaces that are desirable proceed in the absence of knowledge of the mechanisms that endow fibrous interfaces with toughness, and unsurprisingly have very high failure rates of up to a nearly unbelievable 94%. By developing and testing the first mathematical models for the toughness of this class of interfaces, we hope to identify the mechanisms of toughening definitively, and more broadly to provide technology that enables design of improved surgical procedures.

PHR: At-risk alcohol use, alcohol use disorder and return to drinking can have negative impacts on people with HIV (PWH). We propose to integrate alcohol reduction and relapse prevention interventions into HIV clinical care settings and to study the long-term effects of the spectrum of alcohol use on the alcohol and HIV care continua, comorbidities and disparities among a large, multi-site cohort of PWH.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This project aims to bridge the gap between assistive devices and rehabilitative tools so that stroke patients with a paretic arm can immediately return to their daily routine and use their activities of daily living as a patient-specific rehabilitation strategy. Assistive bionic exoskeletons will be intuitively controlled with residual muscle activity from the paretic arm, and artificial intelligence will elucidate underlying muscle impairment, improve the dexterity of bionic devices, and temporarily assist and rehabilitate stroke patients. This proposal is relevant to NIH’s mission because it has strong potential to improve quality of life for stroke patients and their caregivers, as well as reduce overall healthcare costs.

PHR: Project Narrative Patients with no-option critical limb ischemia (CLI) face to major limb amputations and huge health care costs. We propose to develop novel gene therapy, which employs E-selectin to prime ischemic limb to increase neovascularization and regeneration in ischemic tissues while decreasing tissue damage. It will ultimately eliminate the need for amputation and transform the care for PAD/CLI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is caused by both environmental and genetic factors, but most of the genes responsible for ASD remain unknown, and the functions of most ASD risk genes that have been identified are poorly understood. We will use zebrafish as a vertebrate model system to study the effects of a large number of recently-identified ASD risk genes on brain development and behavior. These studies will improve our understanding of why mutations in specific genes result in ASD and may ultimately lead to novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although fever and pneumonia are the most common symptoms in patients with COVID-19, some patients also show neurological symptoms, including the loss of smell and severe headache or seizure. Little is known about whether SARS-CoV-2 can infect the nervous system or cause neuroinflammation. By investigating the neurological effects of COVID-19, using human studies and mouse models, this project will help uncover novel aspects of SARS-CoV-2 related neuro-pathophysiology and elucidate important factors to consider when treating COVID-19 patients.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The FDA ability to protect the public health is directly related to its ability to access and utilize the latest scientific data. Increased proficiency in collecting, presenting, validating, understanding, and drawing quantitative inference from the massive volume of new scientific results is necessary for success in that effort. The complexity involved requires continued development of new tools available and being developed within the realm of information technology, and the workshops proposed here will address this need. Specific Aims  • Thoroughly understand the resources in Arkansas available for furthering the capabilities in  bioinformatics and its associated needs, e.g., access to high speed computing capability and use  of computational tools. • Develop a set of plans to harness and grow those capabilities, especially those that are relevant  to the needs of NCTR and FDA. • Stimulate interest and capability across Arkansas in bioinformatics to produce a larger cadre of  expertise as these plans are implemented. • Enlist NCTR’s help in directing the effort toward seeking local, national and international data  that can be more effectively analyzed to produce results needed by FDA and others, e.g.,  reviewing decades of genomic/treatment data on myeloma patients at the University of  Arkansas for Medical Sciences. • Develop ways in which the Arkansas capabilities can be combined into a coordinated, synergistic  force larger than the sum of its parts. • Encourage students and faculty in the development of new models and techniques to be used in  bioinformatics and related fields. • Improve inter-institutional communication, including developing standardized bioinformatics  curricula and more universal course acceptance.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Arkansas Bioinformatics Consortium

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social connection during pregnancy is a well-established buffer for prenatal stress known to predict better infant and maternal health in the postpartum period. This study examines how social disruption, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, affects expectant parents and their subsequent mental health, birth outcomes, and infant development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The recent COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the critical unmet need for effective treatments for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) that would mitigate not only against lung injury but also ARDS-associated brain injury. We will test a novel approach to treat both lung and brain injury in ARDS with intravenously administered naïve B cells. We propose that B cells migrate into the sites of injury where they suppress inflammation and promote healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Right ventricular-arterial uncoupling is strongly associated with poor outcomes in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Significant changes in both passive stiffness and contractile characteristics of the right ventricle are evident in pulmonary hypertension patients, and the competition between these changes is expected to result in either the preservation or loss of ventricular-arterial coupling. The studies proposed in this application investigate the stiffness-to-contractility ratio as a novel biomechanical marker that predicts the ability of the right ventricle to preserve ventricular-arterial coupling. Further, the proposed studies develop and validate an integrated artificial intelligence-echocardiography technology to feasibly quantify this marker in vivo and use it to identify patients at risk of ventricular-arterial uncoupling in settings of pulmonary hypertension.
