IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary complications are the most common cause of death in patients with sickle cell disease and are thought to be caused by the release of toxins during the breakdown of red blood cells. This proposal expands on our previous work to identify the role of hemin, a toxin released during breakdown of red blood cells, in the development of these pulmonary complications, namely pulmonary hypertension and acute chest syndrome. We use preclinical models as well as genomic data from sickle cell disease patients to better understand these deadly complications in order to develop new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common form of congenital heart disease in children involves incomplete division of the ventricles, known as ventricular septal defects. We have identified a cell population in the early embryo that contributes to the formation of the septa between ventricular heart chambers and forms a cell boundary to prevent mixing of cells between the left ventricle and the right ventricle. We will study how two candidate pathways control this boundary for L-R patterning of the interventricular septum, and how disruptions lead to ventricular septal defects.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE The Centers of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (CERSI) program allows the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to form extramural partnerships that foster robust and innovative research to develop new tools, standards, and approaches to assess the safety, efficacy, quality, and performance of FDA- regulated products, supporting regulatory decision-making and the overall mission of the FDA. Over the past seven years, the Yale-Mayo Clinic CERSI has pursued a series of innovative research projects that leverage real-world data sources to assess the safety, efficacy, quality, and performance of FDA-regulated products, informing regulatory decision-making as well as manufacturers, clinicians, and patients in support of optimizing patient-centered care, along with providing and supporting high-quality mentorship and training in regulatory science. The Yale-Mayo Clinic CERSI will continue this work, conducting high-quality, high-impact regulatory science research in priority areas identified by the FDA to modernize development and evaluation of FDA- regulated products, strengthen post-market surveillance and labelling of FDA-regulated products, and invigorate public health preparedness and response of FDA, patients, and consumers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Yale-Mayo Clinic FDA Center of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (CERSI)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will collect longitudinal data from 450 Latino immigrant adults varying in context of migration to examine how exposure to food insecurity and trauma – concurrently and prospectively influence risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diminished psychological well-being via the biological pathways of malnutrition and systemic inflammation, along with identifying individual and cultural protective factors. Using state-of-the-art biomarkers and mixed methods, this is the first study to identify multi-domain, multi-level factors that promote resilience in this immigrant population at the biological level, as well as qualitatively, and therefore takes first steps towards the development of novel therapeutics to address disparities in CVD and psychological well-being among Latino immigrants. Knowledge gained from this study will propel scientific evidence about biobehavioral mechanisms through which food insecurity influences health risk and contributes to health disparities, as well as inform culture and context sensitive assessments, prevention efforts, interventions, and policies for a marginalized immigrant population about which little is known.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In patients with open heart surgery and organ transplant, an enzyme called plasmin breaks down blood clots and contributes significantly to bleeding. In high risk cardiac surgery, inhibition of plasmin by its inhibitor bovine aprotinin was very successful, but this drug is discontinued as it caused severe organ damage. Studies proposed in this application have the potential to develop a substitute for aprotinin and lysine analogs, which would be more efficacious, safe and of human origin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal Hematopoiesis of Indeterminate Potential (CHIP) is a condition of aging and is associated with increased risk of heart disease, heart failure and worse outcomes in cancer patients. CHIP involves somatic mutations in peripheral blood stem cells and currently can only be evaluated by DNA sequencing of blood. The proposed research will use cutting edge machine learning methods to elucidate unique imaging features in cardiac MRI to identify subjects with CHIP, predict who with CHIP will develop cardiomyopathy as well as integrate MRI, genomics and transcriptomics to identify pathways contributing to cardiomyopathy and potential personalized therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite decades of research documenting the benefits of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy, this highly effective treatment is not initiated, implemented, or persistently used by the millions of adults worldwide diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) The overall objective of the proposed project is to evaluate a telehealth-delivered adaptive intervention for persons newly diagnosed with OSA that promotes CPAP adherence and improves health outcomes and assess potential mediators and moderators of treatment response. By using an innovative adaptive design and telehealth-delivered approach, study results will directly lead to a more personalized approach to increasing long-term CPAP adherence and improving health outcomes of persons with OSA while simultaneously generating a better understanding of factors that drive CPAP adherence across a variety of personal, social, and economic contextual factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Exercise promotes skeletal muscle health resulting in protection from disease; however, the cell signaling required for these benefits remains unclear. The skeletal muscle is made up of multiple cell types which need to “talk” to each other to coordinate their activities so that the skeletal muscle can support the increased energy demand of exercise. This proposal seeks to understand the underlying signaling in different types of cells required for the beneficial skeletal muscle responses to exercise.

PHR: Project Narrative Full-thickness rotator cuff tears are present in at least 25% of individuals in their 60s and are a common cause of shoulder pain, weakness and dysfunction. 20-30% of patients who undergo rotator cuff repair experience a retear, the causes and clinical implications of which are poorly understood but that may lead to recurrence of symptoms and require re-operation. This proposal aims to better understand the longer-term implications of both successful and failed rotator cuff repair healing in order to inform the clinical management of patients with rotator tears as well as research into interventions aimed to improve healing, joint health and longer-term outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is generally believed that immune responses triggered by transient DNA damage are beneficial while those associated with persistent DNA damage are detrimental. The project aims to investigate a previously unknown crosstalk between DNA damage and immune responses in aging hematopoiesis. If successfully completed, the project would identify a beneficial persistent DNA damage-immune response pathway and its critical role in aging hematopoiesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The objective of this R01 application is to define a novel and critical function of ostecytes through perilacunar/canalicular remodeling to regulate the balance between mineral resorption and mechanical integrity of the maternal skeleton during challenging physiological events such as lactation and menopause. By pursuing this objective we expect to provide new insight into personalized clinical management for osteoporosis in postmenopausal women by considering their pregnancy and lactation histories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The nucleolus is the ribosome factory of the cell. Ribosomes in turn are the cellular machines that synthesize all proteins. The most important component and backbone of ribosomes is its RNAs. Ribosomal RNAs are heavily modified by small RNA-protein complexes to properly exert their func- tions. This process occurs in one of three recognizable subcompartments of the nucleolus, the dense fibrillar component (DFC), which we propose to be formed by the modification activity. One of the two major families of the small RNA-protein complexes are impaired in dyskeratosis congenita.  Patients with the bone marrow failure syndrome dyskeratosis congenita (DC) fail to produce suf- ficient blood cells to carry oxygen and fight infections. Most frequently DC is caused by mutations in proteins that associate with many different small noncoding RNAs that are required for a vast spectrum of cellular functions. Although one of these functions has been shown to be impaired in DC patients, it is not known if and to what extent other functions associated with these RNA–protein complexes are affected. For example, we will investigate if and how these RNA–protein complexes affect the nuclear organelles where they are found, when they are mutated in DC. This proposal aims to answer these questions and to solve the mystery that underlies the nucleolus and DC. The experiments will charac- terize the fine structure of the nucleolus and identify new avenues of treatment for patients with DC and possibly with other bone marrow failure syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current treatment of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) remains focused on symptoms and does not address the underlying structural changes of cardiac remodeling that are key to disease progression. In this study, I will determine the therapeutic potential of Thrombospondin-1 (TSP-1) on the primary structural cardiac changes that occur in HFpEF, including the effect of biological sex. This study will not only establish the therapeutic potential for TSP-1 inhibition in HFpEF and introduce a new therapeutic approach by targeting matrix remodeling, it will also determine TSP-1’s biology and pathobiology in a hierarchical manner from cells to animals and lay the foundation to transfer this therapy to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Cardiovascular disease is the number one cause of death globally and there is a critical lack of regenerative therapies to repair the cardiac damage underlying the high morbidity and mortality rates. I propose to study the mechanisms by which Reptin represses the division of cardiac muscle cells (cardiomyocytes). By understanding how cardiac cell division is regulated, we can develop new therapies to promote cardiomyocytes to divide and permanently repair cardiac damage to heal the underlying cause of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Gastrointestinal (GI) sensation is necessary under physiologic and pathologic conditions, and during inflammation, such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), mediates abdominal pain. The dorsal root ganglia (DRG) sensory neurons provide the sensory innervation to the colon and allow for pain responses. Here, I propose to uncover how subtypes of DRG neurons respond to inflammation and understand the mechanisms through which they mediate mechanosensation and inflammation-induced mechanical hypersensitivity, which will be critical for identifying therapeutic targets to treat IBD- associated abdominal pain.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms of mechanosensation and inflammation-induced hypersensitivityin colon innervating DRG sensory neurons

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Cytochrome filaments with closely stacked hemes were just recently discovered by us to be responsible for long- range electron transfer. These novel conductive nanowires have great potential as biomedical materials, yet much is still unknown about their mechanism of action and biophysical properties. This proposal aims to identify novel cytochrome filaments in respiring prokaryotes, elucidating their conduction mechanism by biophysical approaches, and designing self-assembled nanowires for biomedical applications.

PHR: Narrative Statement We propose continuation of M-CERSI that fosters FDA-oriented research, as well as regulatory science information sharing opportunities. The Center's mission is to foster the development of regulatory science – the science of developing new tools, standards and approaches to assess the safety, efficacy, quality and performance of FDA-regulated products. Activities leverage the close geographic proximity between University of Maryland and FDA's main campus.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the FDA’s need for expanded regulatory science capabilities, the Research Triangle Center of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (Triangle CERSI) will provide a generative community for regulators, academia, and industry while serving as a one-stop-shop accelerator to meet current and evolving needs of regulatory science. The Triangle CERSI represents a collaboration of four leading academic institutions in North Carolina that are in close proximity (the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Duke University, North Carolina State University, and North Carolina Central University). The Triangle CERSI aims to fully deploy our broad, collective expertise and close collaborations with FDA personnel to create and expedite utilization of important new knowledge in regulatory science and to provide an infrastructure of flexible and innovative toolsets to enrich the efficiency and value of FDA activities as part of the national CERSI program.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Triangle Center of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation

In addition, the CERSI develops training and outreach programs for the purpose of training students, postdoctoral fellows and career scientists in regulatory sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The most recent community needs assessment denoted cancer as the most significant health priority in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the second most significant in Queens County. Strategies to decrease cancer burden were identified and included increased outreach and leveraging education and wellness programs to all communities; diverse, underserved, and anyone in our catchment area. With our current system in place Northwell Health NCORP can affect change on health outcomes in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative There are no known evidence-based interventions targeting the prevention of HIV transmission among older Black women in the U.S., which is a major public health concern as there is a growing aging Black American population living with HIV. The objective of this innovative project is to develop and test the feasibility, acceptability, usability, and preliminary efficacy of Woman to Woman (W2W), an HIV intervention for older Black women. The mentorship and training activities, combined with the implementation of the feasibility trial, within this BIRCWH supplement will provide the needed skills and data for the BIRCWH scholar, Dr. Laneshia Conner, to address comments for her competitive K01 to conduct a large scale randomized controlled trial to assess the impact of the W2W intervention in reducing HIV risk among older Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The biguanide drug metformin that is widely used for the management of Type 2 diabetes is being evaluated as an anti- neoplastic agent in cancer trials including GBM. In this proposal we will investigate molecular markers for metformin therapy and mechanisms of resistance to metformin therapy in glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We develop the multiplexed super-resolution force spectroscopy to investigate the mechanism of ribosome translocation during protein synthesis. We will measure the power strokes from elongation factors and their mutants during ribosome translocation on modified mRNA sequences and in the presence of antibiotics. Our research will provide new model about the ribosome translocation with sub-codon steps and provide potential drug targets for the related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will examine associations between measures of placental function and offspring cardiovascular outcomes across the life course and investigate the placenta as a mediator of racial and socioeconomic disparities in offspring cardiovascular disease (CVD). Results from this research will improve our understanding of the placental mechanisms underlying offspring CVD risk, which in the short-term, will improve identification of neonates who may benefit from enhanced monitoring and early intervention, and in the long-term, will inform development of gestational interventions to promote optimal cardiovascular health and mitigate disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a clinical need to support immune recovery in critically ill patients whose bone marrow dysfunction and immune suppression often lead to poor short and long term outcomes. Emerging evidence shows a critical role of the gut microbiome in controlling hematopoiesis and regulating immune function, therefore enteral nutrition can be therapeutically relevant strategy to modulate the microbiome and support immune recovery. Given our previous work utilizing murine models of antibiotic induced bone marrow failure, we hypothesize that plant based enteral nutrition will provide superior recovery from antibiotic-induced bone marrow suppression via microbial fermentation of dietary fiber and production of SCFAs compared to widely adopted artificial enteral nutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE A persistent trend exists in the science of health care interventions for older adults; some of what we know works does not get provided in everyday routine health care and some interventions that have no benefit continue to be offered and delivered. In this conference series we will increase awareness of the evidence translation gap; we will use specific case studies in multidisciplinary teams to examine the barriers to implementing research and scaling it broadly, or de-implementing interventions that may be harmful or ineffective. Each conference brings together national leaders, key stakeholders, and promising junior and experienced scientists. The goal is to stimulate new collaborations for implementation research that ultimately improves health and independence in old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) is a growth factor expressed in the nervous system to mediate repair after traumatic injuries. GDNF could therefore be used as a medicine to treat spinal cord injuries. However, that protein has unfavorable properties which may prevent it from becoming a drug or even used as a probe in some cellular experiments; this application is to prepare small molecule GDNF mimics which should be efficacious but void of those detrimental characteristics.

PHR: Project Narrative: The identification and classification of the genome is an essential foundation for understanding human physiology. This work will explore the remaining uncharted corners of the genome that are activated during inflammation. By discovering the functions of these unknown regulators of immunity, we hope to uncover novel mechanisms underpinning all human disease and identify new therapeutic targets never before investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic has demonstrated the immense risk posed by the emergence of novel viral strains. There is an urgent need to develop new vaccination approaches to induce broadly protective immunity against highly mutable mucosal viruses, which are likely sources of future pandemics. In this proposal, I will explore how the tissue microenvironment shapes the development of memory B cells following viral infection in order to better understand how vaccines can enhance the antiviral memory B cell response and establish broadly protective immunity against mucosal viruses.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to develop a method to transplant cells and tissue in the absence of chronic systemic immunosuppression, which could lead to improved outcomes in the general population of transplant recipients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: There is an urgent need to train investigators with an understanding of how to conduct research to understand the sex/gender differences in basic disease mechanisms and to understand the heterogeneity of treatment effects by sex/gender in devices, drugs, and other treatments. By harnessing the incredible talent and leveraging the unique resources of the Tufts community, Dr. Freund and Dr. Jaffe have developed and further expanded the Tufts University BIRCWH Scholars Program. This tailored training program for Early Career Investigators focuses on sex and gender differences and women's health research and ensures the training of a cadre of investigators to become the future research leaders in this critical area.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Criminal justice involvement and recidivism are highly prevalent among Veterans and important social determinants of health. Few treatment options with demonstrated effectiveness are available for Justice- Involved Veterans (JIVs). New comprehensive treatments such as Maintaining Independence and Sobriety Through Systems Integration, Outreach, and Networking-Criminal Justice Edition (MISSION-CJ) are emerging and aim to reduce criminal recidivism, improve treatment access and engagement and address other health- related risk factors underlying recidivism (i.e., substance use, mental health, housing, and employment problems). This study will be run in Mental Health Residential Rehabilitation Treatment Programs, and intends to compare MISSION-CJ versus Enhanced Usual Care, the latter of which includes a structured peer support curriculum as well as community outreach and linkage support. The long-term goal is to help the VA reduce criminal recidivism among JIVs, and improve the long-term health of this vulnerable Veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: With PPO prevalence rising, it's crucial to uncover the early mechanisms of renal disease that increase CKD risk in adulthood. This proposal utilizes the SSLepRmutant rat to study how alterations in energy metabolism in PT contribute to early renal injury in PPO. The research aims to identify how IR affects PT glucose metabolism during renal injury and evaluate interventions to reduce IR, thus improving PT function and clinical outcomes for obese children with renal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The recent and ongoing outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 highlights the need for a streamlined approach to develop effective antivirals; there are no vaccines or approved antivirals. We propose to apply our established strategies for developing viral-entry preventing peptides to develop SARS-CoV-2 peptide antivirals based on viral genetic information; based on our previous findings we have high confidence that we can provide effective COVID-19 prophylaxis using fusion inhibitors. We will also assess the potential of our antivirals to block host- to-host transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to structurally and functionally characterize the transcription and replication processes in SARS- CoV-2, the causative agent of the devastating disease COVID-19. The viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which collaborates with a host of viral-encoded nucleic acid processing enzymes to establish infection and replication, is the central enzyme of transcription and replication and a proven target for antivirals such as remdesivir. Understanding how these enzymes function together and providing high-resolution structures provides insight that can lead to new therapeutics against this deadly pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 highlights the need for an approach to developing effective antivirals; there are no vaccines or antivirals for SARS-CoV-2. We propose to apply our novel protein engineering strategies in a straightforward approach to developing SARS-CoV-2 peptide antivirals that inhibit entry of the virus into the host cell and are resistant to degradation, and based on our previous findings we have high confidence that we can provide effective prophylaxis using fusion inhibitors in vivo delivered via the airway. We will also assess the therapeutic potential of our antivirals for use in established disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The coronavirus pandemic impacts everyone's lives, cripples health care systems and causes a threat to the U.S. and the global economy. Other than remdesivir and dexamethasone, which display limited efficacy, there is no approved drug for the treatment of COVID-19, especially for prophylaxis and early treatment, and the discovery of an effective vaccine remains uncertain. This project aims to design and develop a safe and effective orally bioavailable antiviral agent targeting the SARS-CoV- 2 3CL protease (3CLpro), a critical viral protein required for virus replication, for the treatment of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) can hijack the normal operations of human cells, which makes it especially dangerous. It encodes a set of nonstructural proteins (nsp) to protect its RNA genome from host degradation and immune restriction. Our studies will combine biochemical, structural, cellular, and genomic approaches to address fundamental questions related to RNA modification, host immune restriction, viral growth and pathogenesis, and develop new molecular tools to collectively inform new treatment for COVID-19 and other emerging viruses and protect ourselves against future viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Off label use of existing drugs may offer protection, yet to date, the repurposed approaches studied for COVID- 19 treatment have demonstrated only modest utility and some have increased morbidity and mortality due to serious side effects. We have discovered a novel class of compounds that targets a host function and effectively suppresses replication of SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2) and other emerging viruses. We will optimize these compounds, determine their therapeutic potential and decipher their mechanism of antiviral action, thereby advancing the development of a class of antivirals that can provide readiness for resurge of COVID-19 and future outbreaks with coronaviruses and other newly emerging viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rigorous research is needed to identify mechanisms contributing to sexual minority health disparities, particularly from an intersectionality perspective. The intersectionality of geographic location and sexual orientation can profoundly impact prevalence of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, as rural sexual minorities experience disproportionate burden of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, often reside in high-stigma environments, and have limited access to healthcare resources. This project uses an innovative mixed methods approach to clarify acute and dynamic mechanisms underlying suicidal thoughts and behavior disparities among rural sexual minority adults and will inform therapeutic targets for suicide prevention in this uniquely high-risk population.

ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The mortality and morbidity due Sickle Cell Disease, a genetic blood disorder predominantly found in sub- Saharan Africa, has been reduced in high income countries using evidence-based interventions. This project aims to implement innovations including electronic registry, standards of care, as well as cohort and implementation science research to transform SCD outcomes in this setting. The anticipated findings of the project will inform policy formulation and sustainable roll out of evidence-based interventions in Uganda and the rest of sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Our goal is to develop towards an IND a novel class of small molecule inhibitors of phosphoinositide (PI) 4 kinase IIIb (PI4KIIIb) with potent dual activity against both SARS-CoV-2 and the excess cytokine release associated with COVID-19 disease. Our lead inhibitor, STF-1019 has nanomolar antiviral activity, potently inhibits the LPS-induced secretion of IL-6 from human PBMC, is orally bioavailable and well tolerated in mice, although its metabolic stability is suboptimal, requiring co-administration with an inhibitor (i.e. ritonavir) of its metabolism by CYP3A4 for optimal sustained tissue exposure. We now seek to identify an analog of STF-1019 with improved metabolic stability to enable convenient once-a-day dosing so that we can begin to assemble the future IND package.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Heterotopic ossification (HO), characterized by formation of extra-skeletal bone as a consequence to traumatic injury or genetic disorders, is a medical condition that results in significant cost and patient suffering. In this proposal, we aim to clarify the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying this condition and identify potential treatment targets. Results from the proposed studies will not only yield novel insights into the pathogenesis and treatment of HO but may also be applicable to studying a class of diseases that may share similar core mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 2: Narrative Risk-based screening is being studied as an improvement on current age-based approaches but relies on well- performing risk models to be effective. This project aims to advance the genetic models (polygenic risk scores) being used in the WISDOM Study of risk-based screening by: 1) optimizing their cross-ancestry performance; 2) adapting them to better predict fast-growing cancers; and 3) determining how they can be used to identify women who may benefit from shorter intervals of screening. We expect the knowledge generated in Project 2 to advance breast cancer risk prediction, improve the effectiveness of risk-based screening, and facilitate the translation of polygenic risk scores to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3: Narrative Our ongoing WISDOM trial of risk-based breast cancer screening and prevention is predicted to reduce harms from screening by 50% while continuing to reduce advanced breast cancers as much as annual screening; however, the underlying risk model has high potential for improvement. The overall goal of Project 3 is to continuously develop and improve models for predicting the risk of breast cancer by combining emerging advances in artificial intelligence, inherited genetics, and tumor molecular assays. We will use these advanced models to predict risk of fast- vs. slow-growing breast cancer subtypes and to create a next-generation WISDOM risk-based screening and prevention platform, which, based on our preliminary data, we expect will be substantially more useful than the current WISDOM risk model and enable further reduction in harms from both lethal breast cancers and abundant false positives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal seeks to unravel the molecular mechanisms underlying severe non-syndromic cochleovestibular and cochleovestibular nerve malformations. We will employ a comprehensive genomic analysis to identify the key molecular events implicated in the development of these malformations. Our proposed research promises to yield novel insights into inner ear development and can pave the way for the development of better molecular diagnostic tools and future personalized treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is a major public health issue and is often diagnosed in later stages, resulting in an increased risk of death. Extracellular vesicles are nanoscale particles that circulate throughout bodily fluids and are released by all cells, and their cargo may indicate early signs of ovarian cancer or inform better treatment strategies. The proposed training and research will create improved methods for characterizing and classifying extracellular vesicles to improve patient outcomes by developing ultrasensitive detection devices and machine learning analytical tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The UCSF-KPNC Building Interdisciplinary Research Careers in Women’s Health (BIRCWH) Program offers mentored training to scholars to advance women’s health and health equity in the U.S. through the study of sex and gender influences in health and disease. This proposal will directly support the career development of a scholar underrepresented in medicine and help to strengthen a diverse scientific workforce in women’s health research. It will also provide support for a postdoctoral scholar, increasing focus on significant public health issues in women’s health. The program strengthens interdisciplinary research skills and trains women’s health researchers for successful careers in team science focused on topics of public health importance, ultimately improving U.S. health outcomes and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, I aim to use a new method to define a human DNA mutation and a protein named FUBP1 that binds to this mutation as an explanation as to why some people are more likely to develop a deadly blood vessel disease in lungs called pulmonary hypertension. If successful, my work could change our understanding of pulmonary hypertension and drive development of new ways to detect and treat this deadly disease.
